entry.title: Fetching ErrorInformation from CPI Message Processing Logs
entry.content:
The Challenge

The CPI environment uses External Logging to send logs to Splunk. There, the LastError field is readily available:

Important: The LastError field is also populated for messages with status COMPLETED - when an error was caught and handled properly in the iFlow. This is valuable for monitoring because you can see errors that were gracefully handled and potentially returned to the sender system, even though the message processing itself succeeded.

However, when querying the OData v2 API (/api/v1/MessageProcessingLogs), this field is not exposed. The ErrorInformation is only available as a deferred navigation property:

{
  "ErrorInformation": {
    "__deferred": {
      "uri": ".../MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('guid')"
    }
  }
}

What I Tested

$expand=ErrorInformation

GET /MessageProcessingLogs?$expand=ErrorInformation

Result: 501 Not Implemented

This is the most obvious approach, but CPI doesn't support it. There are SAP Influence requests for this:

  • #296909
  • #309960

$select=LastError

GET /MessageProcessingLogs('guid')?$select=MessageGuid,LastError,Status

Result: Field not available in API response

The LastError field exists internally (Splunk receives it), but is not exposed via OData.

OData $batch Request

POST /$batch
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary=batch_123

Result: 404 - The $batch endpoint doesn't exist for MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations

What Works

The only method I found is calling each message individually:

GET /MessageProcessingLogErrorInformations('MessageGuid')/$value

This returns the plain text error message. But for thousands of messages, this means thousands of API calls.

Open Question

I'm currently using parallel HTTP requests as a workaround, but it feels inefficient when Splunk already receives this data automatically via External Logging.

Has anyone found a better approach? Maybe there's an undocumented feature or a way to access the External Logging stream directly?

Let me know in the comments!

Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Why is this Integration required?
  • 2. Prerequisites
  • 3. Technical Integration
  • 3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration
  • 3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • 3.2.1 Create Communication User
  • 3.2.2 Create Communication System
  • 3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement
  • 3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • 3.3.1Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers
  • 3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration
  • 3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment
  • 3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations
  • 3.4 Monitoring
  • 3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
  • 3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating Functional Locations and Equipment master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Risk Management, Incident Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining asset-related data manually within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on validated Plant Maintenance (PM) master data coming from the customer’s existing ERP landscape. This ensures that all structures, machines, and technical objects involved in EHS processes remain consistent, reliable, and audit-proof across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date Functional Location and Equipment data is essential because many EHS processes depend on a clear understanding of where work is performed and which technical objects is affected. This includes:

  • Identifying the exact machine or installation involved in an incident
  • Linking hazards to the correct technical asset in Risk Assessments
  • Performing control inspections and assigning follow-up actions
  • Ensuring asset-specific exposure, material usage, or emission characteristics are correctly evaluated
  • Centralizing reporting across operational sites based on real asset hierarchies

In other words: Without integrated Functional Location and Equipment data, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot reliably assess risks, evaluate hazards, track incidents, or produce compliant operational reports.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post – focusing on the integration of Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Reference to User Scenario (B) – Risk Management

In part 1 “Introduction & Overview”, the User Scenario (B) – Risk Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Plant Maintenance (PM) Integration Matters

A supervisor identifies a hazard in the chemical handling area

The hazard must be assigned to the correct Functional Location to ensure accurate traceability and reporting.

An Industrial Hygienist conducts a risk assessment

Equipment properties (e.g. ventilation units, storage cabinets, extraction systems) must be available from SAP PM to evaluate exposure and technical conditions.

Mitigation actions are defined

Some mitigation measures depend on technical object (e.g., upgrading ventilation, replacing equipment, updating signage).

A control inspection is performed

The inspection must reference the exact equipment or Functional Location where the mitigation is implemented.

Residual risk is recalculated

The correct asset hierarchy ensures that results are assigned to the right operational area or machine.

Results are shared with operations teams

Consistent Functional Location data ensures findings reach the correct plant, work center, or technical area.

Without integrated Functional Locations and Equipment, the system would not be able to:

  • Assign hazards or incidents to the correct asset
  • Trace risk assessments and inspections to the real technical environment
  • Evaluate machine-specific conditions and exposures
  • Monitor the effectiveness of mitigation actions at asset level
  • Ensure accurate reporting across operational areas and sites

Note: When implementing Risk Management as demonstrated in the user scenario, ensure that the relevant scope item 54A – Health & Safety Management (for Risk Management) is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC). This activation enables the Risk Assessment and Control Inspection processes in SAP EHS Public Cloud so that synchronized Functional Locations and Equipment master data can be used consistently.

While this integration is mandatory for Risk Management, it is equally relevant for other EHS use cases such as Incident Management or Emissions Management. In all these processes, consistent asset data provides the foundation for identifying affected areas, assessing technical conditions, and enabling accurate regulatory reporting.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully integrate Plant Maintenance data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via the SAP Integration Suite, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

Tenant Provisioning:  

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant (with activated Plant Maintenance)
  • SAP Integration Suite tenant (Cloud Integration + Event Mesh)

Administrator Access: 

Ensure administrator users exist in all three systems: 

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud: The administrator should have the template role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR assigned to allow the creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements. 
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise: Users with access to the SPRO are required.
  • SAP Integration Suite: A User with admin rights for Event Mesh and iFlow deployment is required.

Scope Item Activation:  

Following scope items need to be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

  • 4HH – Reactive Maintenance (mandatory for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud communication scenario regarding the inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations).
  • 54A – Health & Safety Management (required for Risk Management scenario).

Activated OData Services in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System:

  • API_EQUIPMENT and API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION active in SAP Gateway (check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE).

Event Mesh Instance:

  • Provisioned by SAP BTP with service key available (for AMQP connection).

These prerequisites ensure that the integration of Plant Maintenance – specially changes made in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system – operates smoothly and reliably, thereby supporting EHS processes such as Risk Management.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section provides an overview of the technical integration required to replicate Plant Maintenance master data from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for EHS processes.

The integration scenario builds on the activation of the scope item 4HH – Reactive Maintenance, which delivers the necessary inbound services for Equipment and Functional Locations in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These objects form the foundation for EHS capabilities such as Risk Management, Incident Management, or Emissions Management.

The process shown in this integration scenario is event-driven. This means, whenever changes occur to Plant Maintenance master data, such as Equipment or Functional Location in the On-Premise system, these updates are automatically replicated to the Public Cloud. This approach keeps both systems aligned without manual steps or scheduled batch jobs, ensuring that asset information is always current.

Keeping master data synchronized between both systems is critical for effective Risk Management because risk assessments and mitigation strategies depend on accurate details about assets and their locations.

By ensuring that updates flow seamlessly between systems, organizations can make informed decisions and maintain compliance across their EHS processes.

Key Configuration Areas: 

  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration 
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration 
  • SAP Integration Suite Configuration
  • Monitoring

3.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Configuration

As this integration scenario for Functional Locations and Equipment is event driven, the creation of channels was required in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to publish business events to the SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh.

In this context the channels define the protocol (AMQP), destination (Event Mesh service key), and topic space.

Outbound bindings specify which event topics (e.g., sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*) are sent. This ensures that changes in Functional Locations or Equipment trigger the corresponding iFlows in the SAP Integration Suite.

Channels can be created by navigating to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Administration > Chanel Connection Settings > Manage Channels and Parameters.

Therefore, we created the channel IS_INTERNAL_EVENTMESH which uses the AMQP Protocol.

Event Channels in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

After creating the channel, we added two outbound bindings to define which event topic should be published.

  • sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/*
  • sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/*

Added Outbound Bindings to created Event Channel

This configuration ensures that business events for Functional Locations and Equipment are reliably published from the on-premise system to SAP Integration Suite via Event Mesh, enabling event-driven iFlows without the need for polling.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. 

For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration is used.

By activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. 

To create the Communication Arrangement, we need to create a Communication User as well as a Communication System that will be assigned to the related Communication Arrangement.

3.2.1 Create Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g., user OPN_IN). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored in the Security Material of the SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems. 

Select Maintain Communication Users

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app “Maintain Communication Users”.  

Select "New"

If no suitable user exists, select “New” to create one.

Created Communication User - General Data

The username and password for Basic Authentication can be freely defined. 

Related Communication System and Arrangements

Once created, the system automatically structures the user view, showing assignments to Communication Systems and Arrangements (added in later steps). 

3.2.2 Create Communication System

The Communication System is a necessary component for the Communication Arrangement. If you have already set up a Communication System for the S/4HANA On-Premise system, you can use it for the Communication Arrangement. Please note that the previously created Communication User must be assigned to this system for the following steps. Furthermore, no additional system-level settings (regarding outbound communication) are necessary, as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses inbound services.

If no related user exists, you can create a new one as follows: Navigate to the S/4HANA Public Cloud app “Communication Systems”.

Select Communication Systems

Select “New”.

Select "New"

Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise tenant and proceed with the set up. 

Creating new Communication System

Select Inbound Only as the communication scenario SAP_COM_0395 only uses Inbound Communication.

Select Inbound Only

Assign the previously created Communication User.

Assign Communication User

3.2.3 Create Communication Arrangement

The final step in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components  (Communication User and Communication System) within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0395 – Asset Management Master Data Integration). 

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated Plant Maintenance master data (e. g. Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication. 

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the “Communication Arrangements” app. 

Select Communication Arrangements

Then click on “New” to create a new Communication Arrangement. 

Select "New"

Select Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

Choose SAP_COM_0395 as the Communication Scenario.

Choose Communication Scenario SAP_COM_0395

After the creation of the Communication Arrangement the before created Communication System will be attached. Note that the corresponding Communication User will be determined automatically.

Communication System and User

The Inbound Service of the Communication Arrangement provides us then the Service URL, that will be used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.  

Required Inbound Services

3.3 SAP Integration Suite Configuration

In this integration scenario we used the SAP Integration Suite as the middleware layer to enable secure and reliable data exchange between the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Therefore, the SAP Integration Suite is responsible for retrieving Plant Maintenance master data (such as Functional Locations and Equipment) from the On-Premise system and delivering it to the Public Cloud using event-driven integration flows.

Since there is no pre-delivered integration package available for this scenario, we created two custom iFlows to handle the replication of Functional Location and Equipment data. Both iFlows follow a similar structure in terms of processing logic; however, they differ in the endpoints used for communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the On-Premise system respectively.

Custom Integration Package for this Scenario

3.3.1 Establishing the Event Queue for On-Premise Triggers

The first step in this implementation is to create an Event Queue in SAP Event Mesh using the Message Client. This queue serves as the trigger point for event-driven integration. When a change occurs in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system (such as an update to Functional Locations or Equipment), an event is published to the queue.

The iFlow will be later subscribed to the Event Queue and use the event as a trigger to start processing. Once triggered, the iFlow calls the related API in the On-Premise system to retrieve the full master data for the affected object. This design ensures that updates are replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud in near real-time, keeping both systems synchronized.

Note: The SAP Event Mesh – Message client is typically provisioned by the BASIS administrator. If you have no existing Message Client, please refer to your BASIS team.

Once the message client was set up, navigate to it inside the SAP Integration Suite > Configure > Event Mesh.

Navigate to Message Client in SAP Integration Suite

Since our EHS scenario relates to Functional Locations and Equipment, we have created two separate event queues here. Therefore, select Create.

Select "Create"

Enter a name for the new Event Queue(e. g. opn.equipment). You can keep the remaining fields as default.

Queue Settings for opn.equipment

Then navigate to Subscriptions and select Create.

Select "Create"

Two Topic Subscriptions were required within the Event Queue Details for the Equipment:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Created/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/de/ce/sap/s4/beh/equipment/v1/Equipment/Changed/v1

Note: Regarding the Subscription, the message-client-prefix will be typically provisioned by your BASIS team. The remaining part of the respective topic names of the Equipment event is SAP standard and can be viewed in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Equipment Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Repeat this step also for the Functional Location. Therefore again, enter a name for the new event queue (e. g. opn.FuncLoc). The following subscriptions are needed for this event queue:

  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Changed/v1
  • <message-client-prefix>/ce/sap/s4/beh/functionallocation/v1/FunctionalLocation/Created/v1

The Functional Location events for the Functional Locations can be found in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub in the tab Event References Event References | Functional Location Events | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

3.3.2 Integration Credential Configuration

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the created integration flows (iFlows) must authenticate against three endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud – to push the synchronized data to the cloud system.
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise – to retrieve Functional Location and Equipment data
  • SAP Event Mesh – to consume events via AMQP protocol and trigger the integration process.

Note: To ensure secure authentication for each endpoint used by the iFlow, a dedicated Security Material object was created for every connection. In our demo environment, Basic Authentication was sufficient; however, for productive landscapes, certificate-based authentication is required to meet security standards and comply with enterprise policies.

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used in this scenario. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Security Material

The Security Material that was used for communication with the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, was created in a similar way using Basic Authentication, based on the credentials of the On-Premise user. Note that the On-Premise user will be provided by your SAP BASIS team.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise Security Material

For the Event Mesh Security Material that enables communication with SAP Event Mesh, OAuth 2.0 was used for authentication. Therefore, enter the Token Service URL, Client ID and Client Secret, which are provided by the service key of your SAP Event Mesh Instance in SAP BTP Cockpit.

SAP Integration Suite - Event Mesh Security Material

3.3.3 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup - Equipment

Regarding the iFlows we will setup the Equipment Integration iFlow first. Therefore, create the iFlow with a corresponding name, set SAP S/4HANA as Sender and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as Receiver.

Sender and Receiver Setup for Equipment iFlow

The integration flow starts with an AMQP connection to SAP Event Mesh. This connection allows the iFlow to subscribe to event queues and consume messages whenever Functional Location or Equipment changes occur in the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. The AMQP protocol ensures reliable, event-driven communication between the systems and acts as the trigger for the subsequent OData calls.

Therefore, connect the Receiver with the Start Message using the Adapter Type AMQP with Websocket as Transport Protocol.

First iFlow Step - AMQP Adapter Setup

The General tab inside the Adapter can stay as default. In the Connection tab you need to add a Host, Port and Path of the Event Mesh Service Key. You will find this Service Key in the Event Mesh Instance of your SAP BTP Cockpit. For Authentication use OAuth 2.0 and add the associated Security Material for Event Mesh (created in the previous step) as Credential Name.

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

AMQP Adapter Connection Setup

In the Processing tab, add the event queue name for the equipment.

Assign Event Queue opn.equipment to AMQP Adapter

The incoming event message from SAP Event Mesh is delivered in JSON format. Since subsequent processing steps and OData calls require XML, the JSON to XML Converter transforms the payload accordingly. In this scenario, namespace mapping is disabled because the JSON structure does not include namespaces that need to be preserved in the XML output. The remaining parts of the Converter can stay as default.

JSON to XML Converter

After the conversion to XML, we added a Content Modifier. This Content Modifier is used to extract specific values from the XML structure and store them as Message Header and Exchange Properties.

Content Modifier Setup - General

In the Message Header tab, the Content Modifier reads values from the XML payload using XPath and sets them as message headers. In our example, we set the SAP_ApplicationID header with the Functional Location value found at /root/data/Equipment in the XML.

Content Modifier Setup - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab, the Content Modifier creates two properties by extracting values from the XML payload using XPath: p_eventType from /root/type and p_equipmentno from /root/data/Equipment. These properties are later used to dynamically build the OData request URL for the GET call to the on-premise system.

Content Modifier Setup - Exchange Property

Next, we set a Request Reply with the name Get Equipment Data. This enables us to get the data via OData Adapter from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Connection tab of the OData adapter, we define how the integration flow connects to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system. In our example, the address consists of the virtual host and port provided by the SAP Cloud Connector, followed by the OData service path /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_EQUIPMENT/, which is the standard endpoint for the Equipment API in SAP Gateway. The proxy type is set to “On-Premise”, and the Location ID refers to the configured Cloud Connector destination (can be found in the Master Instance for your Cloud Connector in the SAP BTP Cockpit > Logged in into your Subaccount > Connectivity > Cloud Connectors). Regarding the authentication, was used with the on-premise related Security Material.

Note: We leveraged an existing SAP Cloud Connector configuration to securely connect the SAP Integration Suite to the on-premise system without exposing the real backend host.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Connection

Note that the API_EQUIPMENT is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_EQUIPMENT OData Service.  

In the Processing tab, we configured a GET operation to the Resource Path Equipment. Therefore, click Select.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose Connection Source Remote. The fields will be automatically filled with the provided data in the Connection tab. Then click on Step 2. If the connection is configured correctly, we will configure the operation and entities here.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Then select the operation “GET”, the Select Entity “Equipment”, the Sub Levels 1 and choose “Select All Fields”.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

To retrieve only the changes for the specific Equipment Number, apply a filter on the property ${property.p_equipmentno} that was set in the Content Modifier earlier. Filter for the ValidityEndDate as shown below.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 3

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 4

After retrieving the equipment data from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we ensured with a message mapping step that the structure and fields of the incoming data match with the expected values for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For our related message mapping we used a predefined mapping resource (/MM.mmap) created in the iFlow to transform the received data to the expected structure.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

After completing the mapping as required for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Equipment Inbound Service, we set a new Request Reply with an OData V2 adapter to the receiver endpoint of the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

In the Connection tab add the inbound service URL for the Equipment provided by the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395 in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

Choose Proxy Type Internet and add your Security Material that was created for communication with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Basic Authentication.

As we want to send the structure which the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system expects, we need to create new processing details for this OData Adapter. Therefore, choose the Processing tab and navigate to Select.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing

Choose again the Connection Source Remote. The required details to connect with the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system will be shown here again automatically after the previous details in the Connection tab have been configured. Then navigate to Step 2.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 1

Now choose the Operation Post, Entity Equipment, Sub Levels 1 and Select All Fields. For the Post operation no filters are required.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration 2

Note: The iFlow also shows an Exception Subprocess. You can perform this after the implementation of the iFlow is finished. In our scenario we let the Exception Subprocess empty.

Exception Subprocess

3.3.4 Integration Flow (iFlow) Setup – Functional Locations

The iFlow for the Functional Locations was similar in architecture, with small changes.

Created iFlow for Functional Location

For the AMQP Adapter at beginning of the iFlow, the event queue for Functional Location was used.

Used Event Queue in iFlow Funcional Location

According to Content Modifier > Message Header, the used Source Value was /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Message Header

In the Exchange Property tab of the Content Modifier, we changed the second line entry to the Name p_functionallocation and its Source Value to /root/data/FunctionalLocation.

Content Modifier in iFlow Functional Location - Exchange Property

According to the Get Functional Location Data that will perform a GET operation to the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system, we used the OData Service for “API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION” with the root address /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION/. Note again that the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION is activated in your on-premise system. You can check this via the transaction /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE and searching for the API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION OData Service. 

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

In the Processing tab navigate to Select and go to Step 2 (As the fields required for the system connection will be filled automatically).

Choose the Operation and Select Entity as shown below with Sub Level 1 and Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA On-Premise OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

Regarding the query, we were only filtering for FunctionalLocationLabelName equals ${property.p_functionallocation}.

The Message Mapping now needs to be performed for the Functional Location. Therefore, we used again the Resource /MM.mmap but now with a new mapping.

Message Mapping 1

Message Mapping 2

For the last OData Adapter sending the transformed Functional Location data from the SAP Integration Suite to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Inbound Service URL for the Functional Location was used in the Address Field of the Connection Details.

Request Reply with OData Adapter to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System - Connection

Inbound Service URL for Equipment in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0395

According to the Processing details, the connection to the system will be again filled automatically. Then Navigate to Step 2 and choose the Select Entity as well as the Operation as shown below. Choose again Select All Fields.

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud OData Adapter Setup - Processing - Resource Path Configuration

3.4 Monitoring

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that event-driven integration for EHS Risk Management runs reliably across SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud & On-Premise) and the SAP Integration Suite. Accurate and timely event processing is essential because many risk-related processes depend on these events. Missing or delayed events can lead to incomplete risk assessments, gaps in safety measures, and potential compliance violations.

The Monitoring can be performed at all three involved systems.

3.4.1 SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

Regarding the Outbound Events that are sent from the on-premise system to the SAP Integration Suite, you can navigate to SPRO > ABAP Platform > Enterprise Event Enablement > Monitoring > Monitor Event Queues.

If any failures for the Outbound Events occur, they can be analyzed here.

Event Monitor in SAP S/4HANA On-Premise System

3.4.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, monitoring focuses on API communication rather than event queues. The primary tool that can be used here is the “OData Error Log” app, which provides detailed error messages for failed OData requests. This is essential for troubleshooting issues when SAP Integration Suite sends data to the Public Cloud system.

OData Error Log in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud System

3.4.3 SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows. As already described already in the part 2 you can therefore navigate within the SAP Integration Suite to Monitor > Overview > Manage Integration Content. Here you can select your respective iFlow (e.g. “Functional Location Integration in between SAP S4HANA and SAP S4HANA Cloud”) and select Monitor Message Processing.

Manage Integration Content for Functional Location iFlow

This view provides a clear overview of the processing status for each message, indicating whether it was completed successfully or if any errors occurred during execution.

Monitor Message Processing

By selecting Message Status Overview on the upper right corner,  statistics will be shown across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues. 

Message Status Overview

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing this integration scenario via the scope item 4HH for Plant Maintenance data (such as Functional Locations or Equipment) from the SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provided several valuable insights that are highly relevant for similar integration projects.

1. Event-Driven Integration Ensures Real-Time Accuracy: Using SAP Event Mesh with AMQP is critical for keeping Functional Location and Equipment data synchronized. Batch jobs cannot guarantee timely updates for EHS processes like Risk Management.

2. Validate OData Services Early: Missing activation of API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION in the on-premise system is a common root cause for iFlow failures. Always check via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE before starting.

3. Topic Naming in Event Mesh Requires Precision: Incorrect prefixes or typos in topic subscriptions will block event processing entirely. Always cross-check against SAP Business Accelerator Hub references.

4. Message Mapping Is Compliance-Critical: Ensure that Equipment and Functional Location data is transformed correctly for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Missing mandatory fields can lead to incomplete risk assessments and reporting gaps.

5. Monitoring Is Essential for Operational Reliability: Event-driven integration depends on timely message processing. Use monitoring tools in all three systems (SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud) to detect and resolve issues early.

6. Plan Authentication Strategy Upfront: Basic Authentication works for demos, but production environments require certificate-based authentication. Delaying this switch can cause project delays and security risks.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

entry.title: Handling High-Frequency message Integration in SAP CPI with SFTP Append Mode Issues
entry.content:
Introduction

Recently we worked on a high-frequency interface using SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to process a continuous stream of IDocs from a source system. The requirement was to map these IDocs, and send the mapped content to a target system using SFTP. All messages needed to be appended to a single file, and that file was picked up and processed by a job every 5 minutes at the target side.

At first glance, this looked like a simple scenario, but it turned out to be a tricky problem due to the way SFTP receiver works in high-frequency situations.

Problem Statement

We received a high volume of IDocs per minute, and our CPI iFlow was designed to do the following:

Map incoming IDocs to the target structure.

Use the SFTP Receiver Adapter and append to write to a single file for 5 mins after this  the downstream job process every 5 minutes. However, the target system experienced significant problems with increased load.

1. NULL characters in random lines.

2. Truncation of data.

Final file was corrupted or incomplete and therefore unusable. Final file was looking like below:

We noted the following:

The SFTP Adapter in Append Mode cannot support concurrent writes. When multiple CPI threads attempted to append concurrently:

  • Some I/O calls overlapped.
  • File locks failed.
  • The content was corrupted (e.g. NULL characters, partial lines).

CPI does not guarantee ordered or transactional writes when multiple messages are attempting to access the SFTP channel at the same time.

Solution:

To resolve the issue, we redesigned the solution as 2 separate iFlows utilizing Data Store.

iFlow 1 - Message Processing and Write to Data Store

This iFlow receives Idoc from the SAP system and after doing the map it stores the file to the DataStore.

 

Iflow step details:

  • Set header and Content: This is used to set custom header and properties required for processing and logging.
  • Message Mapping: here Idoc structure is mapped to the required target structure.
  • Write: The transformed structure is then write to the Data Store for the next step. This structure should be in XML format for the next step to read it.

iFlow 2 – Aggregation and SFTP File Upload

This iFlow is triggered by a Timer every 5 minutes. It reads all messages stored earlier by the 1st iFlow.

  • We have used Data Store Select to fetch all unprocessed messages in the interval of 5 mins. We have given the number of messages as 500, so that it will pull all the files written by 1st flow on DataStore.

 "Delete on Completion" This check we have selected such that no file will be processed twice after successful processing of the file.

We have given the Number of polled messages as 500, so that it will pick up all the messages that were stored in datastore during last 5 mins. If any data left it will be processed in next poll.

  • When Select step is picking the file up from the data store it combines all the files in the following structure.

In my case the file was looking as below:

We have used a simple groovy to collect all the data between the tag <data> and appended them to create a CSV file

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Get XML as string
    def body = message.getBody(String)

    // Parse XML using XmlSlurper
    def root = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body)

    // Collect all <data> elements
    def dataLines = root.message.record.data.collect { it.text() }

    // Create CSV string with LF at end
    def csv = dataLines.join("\n") + "\n"

    // Set CSV as new body
    message.setBody(csv)
    return message
}

After the groovy the file looks like as below:

This approach created the file which behaves like Append Mode but in a safe, sequential, and controlled manner.

The resulting content is then sent to the target using the SFTP Receiver Adapter.

In conclusion, this method ensures data integrity, sequential processing, and improved performance by safely simulating append mode of SFTP receiver adapter.
No concurrency issues
No file corruption
Scalable for high-volume scenarios

Thank you.

entry.title: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
“In the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.” – Albert Einstein

Handling large-volume data integration is something every integration specialist meets sooner or later. Recently, our team faced one of those “opportunities”—a requirement to transfer around 10 million records from a source system to a target application using SAP Integration Suite (IS) formerly called as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI).

At first glance, the mapping requirements were straightforward. But as always, the devil hides in the details: the pagination behavior of the OData V4 adapter, the Integration Suite processing limits, and unforeseen behavioral quirks pushed us through several attempts before landing on a robust solution.

This blog walks through:

  • What approaches we tried
  • Why they failed
  • What finally worked
  • Key learnings for anyone building high-volume integrations on SAP IS

Context: The Scenario

The source system exposed data through an OData V4 service. A key limitation we discovered early on:

  • Pagination is fully server-controlled in OData V4 adapter
  • The page size cannot be customized in SAP Integration Suite (e.g., you cannot set it to 1,000 or 10,000) when using the standard OData V4 adapter, it always respects the server-side limit
  • Example: If the server page size is 50,000, SAP IS will always retrieve chunks of 50,000 - nothing less

This limitation became the center of the problem.

Approach 1 — Standard OData V4 Adapter + Looping Process Call

(Expected to work… reality had other plans)

How it worked:

  • Used the OData V4 adapter as-is with server-side pagination
  • Used Looping Process Call to iterate through pages

What happened:

  • If the total data was below 50K, everything worked smoothly
  • Above 50K, the iFlow got stuck in Processing
  • No errors
  • No termination
  • Messages remained frozen for days

Example:

  • Server page size → 50K
  • Data set = 40K → Success
  • Data set = 150K → iFlow stalled indefinitely

Lesson: Looping + uncontrolled server pagination = unpredictable behavior.

Approach 2 — OData V4 Adapter + Custom Pagination Logic

(Better… but still not scalable enough)

This time we added:

  • Custom counter checks
  • Pagination logic in iFlow
  • Looping until full completion

Result:

  • Worked better than Approach 1
  • Successfully processed volumes under ~1 million records
  • Beyond that threshold → iFlow stuck again, still showing Processing but not progressing
  • No runtime error, no bottleneck in MPL — simply a silent stall

Lesson: The bottleneck was structural, not logical.

Approach 3 — Final Working Solution (and the hero of the story)

“Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.” — Leonardo da Vinci

Key idea:

Avoid OData V4 adapter entirely.

Use the Classic HTTP Adapter with explicit control over pagination (via top & skip).

This allowed us to fully control the data fetch size and execution flow.

Our Winning Architecture

Flow 1: Master Controller iFlow

  1. Call the source system via HTTP adapter
  2. Retrieve total record count
  3. Calculate the required number of batches
    • Batch size = server-side max (e.g., 50K)
  4. For each batch, create a message containing only the skip value
  5. Store skip values in Data Store

Example:

Total records = 1,000,000
Batch size = 50,000
Total batches = 20
Stored skip values = 0, 50000, 100000, ...


Flow 2: Worker iFlow

  1. Poll Data Store
  2. Read skip value
  3. Call API using HTTP adapter with parameters:
    $top=50000
    $skip=<value from datastore>
  4. Process the dataset
  5. Deliver to target system

The Big Win

This mechanism:

  • Gave us full control over pagination
  • Completely bypassed OData V4 limitations
  • Handled 10+ MILLION records without stalls
  • Achieved stable throughput
  • No permanent IFlow “Processing” states
  • No invisible bottlenecks

Lesson: If the adapter limits you, take control with HTTP.

Key Learnings

  • SAP Integration Suite is powerful and evolving, but very high-volume scenarios still expose adapter-level limitations
  • OData V4 Adapter may not be suitable for massive pagination-driven extractions in all cases
  • HTTP adapter with custom pagination is a reliable fallback
  • Sometimes the “classic” tool is the best tool

And yes—raising an SAP incident might eventually clarify the root cause, but business timelines forced us to engineer a workaround.

Conclusion

High-volume data integration is never trivial. The key is to experiment, observe system behavior, and design around limitations. Our final approach was not just functional—it was scalable, predictable, and production-proof.

If you’re dealing with similar large dataset transfers in SAP IS, this solution pattern might save you hours of troubleshooting.

Feedback Welcome

I’d love to hear your thoughts, improvements, or other patterns you’ve successfully used for large-volume integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite.

Thank you for reading!

I2Integration Solutions | A Startup

Connect in LinkedIn: I2Integrate

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite – Cloud integration Message Usage analytics details
entry.content:
Introduction

We are excited to share the latest improvements in SAP Integration Suite designed to support key business scenarios related to consumption-based usage tracking.

With these enhancements, users can now gain deeper insights into message consumption across their integration flows and easily download consolidated monthly usage reports.

Before we dive in, you can refer to the definitions of Instance and Message in Integration Suite here:

  • Tenant definition
  • Message definition

 

How to check Cloud Integration capability consumptions as a Subaccount Admin

If you are a subaccount admin and want to know the consumption of the cloud integration capability in Integration Suite service, follow these steps:

  1. Open your subaccount where Cloud Integration capability of Integration Suite service is activated.
  2. In the left navigation pane, click on Usage Analytics. This page displays the consumption details for all services.
  3. You can select a date range (Period) to view usage for a specific timeframe.
  4. After selecting the required period, the table will show detailed consumption for all services. In the table, check the “Service Plan” column for entries related to Integration Suite – messages.
  5. For Cloud Integration (CPI) messages, two entries are important:
    1. Total Cloud Integration Messages (e.g., 658 messages)
    2. Excluded Cloud Integration Messages (Only SAP to SAP) (e.g., 320 messages)
  6. Total Cloud Integration (CPI) Chargeable Messages = Total Cloud Integration Messages - Excluded Cloud Integration Messages.

 

 

In case we want to cross-verify this data at each integration flow level/MPL level, we need to navigate to the Messages Usage tile and follow the below steps:

  1. Ensure your user has the required role (PI_Administrator).
  2. Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions under the Services tab.
  3. Click Go to Application.
  4. Open the Monitoring tab and select Integrations and APIs.
  5. Scroll down to find the Messages Usage tile and click it.

On initial load, it will show the data for the current month.

 

 

Background

As many of you know, the Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite already provides double-click metering details for every integration flow execution.

Based on valuable feedback from our customers, this detailed view has proven useful in:

  • Troubleshooting message volume spikes
  • Identifying specific integration flow that contributes the most in message consumption
  • Understanding how key components (such as Splitter, Retry, or SAP-to-SAP Original Content) impact billable messages

These details are crucial for transparency and cost management, as outlined in the message definition documentation.

 

What’s New

Many customers expressed the need for a monthly consolidated Excel report for each integration flow — including package-level information.
With this new enhancement, users can now:

  • View consolidated monthly message consumption per integration flow and per package
  • Download the report directly from the Message Usage tile in a single click
  • Share usage data easily with Lines of Business (LoBs) for further analysis and discussions

 

Access the Message Usage tile explained above.

  1. Default view shows the current month.

When you open the Message Usage tile, the dashboard automatically loads data for the current month, giving you an immediate overview of your latest message consumption trends.

  1. New Enhancement – Below the chart you will see the consolidated table

This enhanced table provides:

  • Each integration flow’s total message count, including SAP-to-SAP messages
  • The package name associated with each integration flow
    This consolidated view helps you quickly understand usage distribution across packages and identify high-volume integrations.
  1. Download the monthly consolidated report

Simply click the Download button to export the full current monthly report.

 

 

 

Now try to get the previous month’s data

We provide up to 1 year of historical data. To get the previous month’s details, follow the steps below:

  1. Select the previous month’s first and last date

Use the Select Date Range option and choose the start and end dates of the month you want to retrieve.

  1. View the refreshed consolidated table

Once the date range is applied, the table below will automatically refresh, showing the consolidated message usage for the selected month.

  1. Download the monthly consolidated data

Click the Download button to export the full month’s report.
This file can be used for internal reviews, consumption analysis, or cost-related discussions with business teams.

 

 

Advanced Settings for Better Table Control

Along with the consolidated table, we also provide an Advanced Settings option.
Using this feature, you can:

  • Sort the data based on column
  • Filter records to focus on specific integration flows or packages
  • Adjust or reorder columns to view the information in the format that best suits your analysis

These options give you more flexibility to analyse message consumption in .

 

 

Enhanced Troubleshooting

This new capability extends our existing metering feature, which already helps users:

  • Investigate message spikes
  • Drill down into detailed metering data for specific integration flows
  • Use the interactive charts to visualize data based on selected metrics

Now, with the consolidated reporting feature, you get both detailed troubleshooting views and high-level monthly summaries — in one place.

Conclusion

Your feedback has been helpful in shaping these improvements — and we’d love to hear more!
Please share your thoughts, experiences, or suggestions for additional insights you’d like to see in Cloud Integration Capability.

entry.title: SAP Neo Retires – Integration Developers Must Know Before Migrating from Neo to CF
entry.content:
SAP has announced the end of maintenance for the SAP Cloud Integration Neo environment by December 31, 2028. This impacts customers running Cloud Integration on Neo and planning to move to the Cloud Foundry–based SAP Integration Suite.

Migrating integration flows from Neo to Cloud Foundry is not a simple export/import of iflows.
Both environments differ significantly in:

  • Infrastructure
  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & monitoring
  • Environment variables
  • APIs
  • Security materials
  • Transport & lifecycle management

This blog summarizes the key Neo vs. Cloud Foundry differences you must consider before starting your CPI migration.

1. Cloud Integration Availability: Neo vs. Cloud Foundry

Neo

  • CPI is available as a standalone product
  • Runs in SAP-managed data centers
  • Uses Neo cockpit & proprietary deployment mechanisms

Cloud Foundry

  • CPI is part of the SAP Integration Suite capability
  • Runs on hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Uses standard CF principles for scaling, service bindings, logging

📌Important: Some Neo features may not be available or behave differently in CF (refer to Note 2903776).

2. Adapter Deployment Differences

Neo

  • Custom adapters deployed using Eclipse plugin
  • Adapter artifacts managed in Neo cockpit

Cloud Foundry

  • Custom adapters are deployed as Integration Adapter artifacts
  • Managed via Cloud Integration Design & Monitor applications
  • Deployment uses CF-based lifecycle mechanisms

Impact:
If you have custom adapters built for Neo, they must be rebuilt or repackaged for Cloud Foundry. Here is the help document to create custom adapters Developing Customer Adapters

3. Logging Differences - Audit Logs & Access Logs

Neo

  • Audit logs retrieved via Neo Audit Log API
  • Access logs available under “Access Logs” section

Cloud Foundry

  • Audit logs available through SAP Audit Log Service
  • Access logs integrated with Application Logs
  • Monitoring done via Cloud Integration Monitor

Impact:
Integrations relying on Neo-specific APIs must be redesigned for CF logging services. Here is the help document related to Audit logging in CF environment Audit Logging in CF 

4. Environment Variables - Critical Migration Topic

We can use environment variables in integration flows to address technical details like the region,port..etc where Cloud Integration is deployed.

The following table provides the mapping of environment variables in Neo and Cloud Foundry.

 

Variable Name - NeoVariable Name -CFDescription

HC_APPLICATION

Example value: abcd01iflmap

TENANT_NAME

Example value: xyz001

Sub domain of worker application (associated with application identifier for worker node)

HC_APPLICATION_URL

Example value: abcd01iflmap.uvwxy.eu1.hana.ondemand.com

TENANT_NAME + IT_SYSTEM_ID + IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: xyz001.it-cpi001.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

URL of the worker application sub domain

HC_HOST

Example value: hana.ondemand.com

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Base URL of the SAP BTP region host where the application is deployed

HC_LOCAL_HTTP_PORT

Example value: 9001

PORT

Example value: 8080

HTTP port of the application bound to localhost

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_HOST

VCAP_SERVICES

Host of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_OP_HTTP_PROXY_PORT

Example value: 20003

VCAP_SERVICES

Example value: 20003

Port of the HTTP Proxy for on-premise connectivity

HC_REGION

Example value: EU_1

IT_TENANT_UX_DOMAIN

Example value: cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com

Region where the application is deployed

Here is the nice blog on how to call/get environment variable in CF Integration flows - identify-sap-cloud-integration-tenant-stage-at-runtime 

5. OData API Access Considerations

Neo

  • Uses Neo-based OAuth clients
  • API base URLs differ
  • Some OAuth grant types are Neo-specific

Cloud Foundry

  • Requires enabling API clients via XSUAA
  • Uses Integration Suite base URLs
  • Authentication flows must be updated

For example:
If you use CPI OData APIs for CI/CD, monitoring, or automation, the endpoints and tokens must be regenerated. Here is the help document gives more details on inbound communication setup - connection setup for inbound communication for api clients 

6. Transport Management & Lifecycle Changes

For the transport of integration content across different tenants, different options are available:

  • Manual export and import
  • Usage of CTS+
  • Usage of the cloud-based Transport Management

These options are identical independent of the environment (Cloud Foundry or Neo). However, setting up transport management using the cloud-based Transport Management service is different in both environments

7. Security Materials (Certificates, Keys, OAuth)

Neo

  • Keystore stored and managed directly inside Neo cockpit
  • OAuth clients created using Neo administration tools

Cloud Foundry

  • Uses Service Instances for trust stores
  • Certificates and keys must be re-imported
  • OAuth clients created via Integration Suite

Impact:
Rebuild all security configurations - especially if you use SFTP, AS2, OData, or SOAP with certificates.

8. Custom Scripting Adjustments (Groovy/JavaScript)

Some scripts refer to Neo-specific:

  • Endpoints
  • Log files
  • Environment variables
  • Adapter classes
  • Tenant metadata

These must be refactored to support CF equivalents.

9. Monitoring Experience Differences

Neo

  • Heavy reliance on Neo cockpit
  • Simplified logging UI
  • Access logs separate from application logs

CF

  • CPI Monitor in Integration Suite
  • Centralized message processing logs
  • Audit logging via SAP Audit Log Service
  • Better integrations with external monitoring tools

Impact:
Monitoring dashboards and alerting need reconfiguration.

Conclusion

Migrating SAP Cloud Integration from Neo to Cloud Foundry is a strategic, time-sensitive initiative as Neo retires in 2028. However, the migration is not a technical copy-paste.
Neo and Cloud Foundry differ significantly in:

  • Adapter deployment
  • Logging & audit mechanisms
  • Environment variables
  • OAuth & API access
  • Transport landscape
  • Runtime services
  • Security configuration

By understanding these environment-specific differences early - and adjusting integration flows, scripts, endpoints, and credentials accordingly - you can avoid migration failures, reduce manual fixes, and ensure a smooth transition to the SAP Integration Suite on Cloud Foundry.

If planned well, the Cloud Foundry environment offers:

  • Better scalability
  • CI/CD readiness
  • Modern logging and monitoring
  • Hyperscaler flexibility
  • Improved integration lifecycle governance

The best time to start preparing is now.

entry.title: How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes
entry.content:
How to Scale AI: The importance of modernizing data and integrating processes

Read the original article here

Expectations of the potential impact of AI have never been higher. But so far, most projects have only produced incremental improvements in isolated areas. So, what do you have to do to get AI to deliver material change across your business? The answer lies in preparing your processes and data—getting them into a condition where AI can use them to deliver on its promise of radical transformation. In this thought provoking article, two AI experts from SAP explain what’s involved, where to get started, and which SAP solutions can help you really put AI to work.

About the authors:

Jürgen Butsmann is part of the SAP Cloud ERP Product Marketing team responsible for AI in the context of SAP S/4HANA, finance and digital supply chain. Jürgen has been with SAP for more than 26 years.  He is a recognized expert for SAP S/4HANA and SAP BTP .

Terry Penner is part of the SAP BTP product marketing team, focused on SAP BTP for Cloud ERP. He has more than 25 years of technical and business experience in the SAP platform and analytics, including working directly on hundreds of customer implementations and presenting on SAP technology topics at conferences around the world.

 

The challenges in reaching AI’s potential

Business leaders believe AI has the potential to transform their organizations.  They see it accelerating cycle times, reducing errors, performing processes automatically, and yielding insights. Their initial experiments and projects have reinforced this expectation by delivering productivity improvements, albeit in isolated areas.

However, return on investment has so far been disappointing and IT teams are finding it challenging to scale AI beyond point solutions. They’re also nervous for ethical and security reasons about exposing their proprietary business data to public large language  models (LLMs).

Observations from customers

The discussions we’ve been having with SAP customers have revealed these common challenges IT leaders face in realizing AI’s potential.

  • Insecure architecture. Using public LLMs alone is not always reliable. AI really needs to use the organization’s own business data. But exposing corporate data to LLMs raises security and ethical issues.
  • Fragmented systems. Applying AI to a process that is contained within a single system is relatively easy. But most real business processes span multiple departments and systems. Often these applications and their data are not integrated which prevents AI from carrying out business processes end to end.
  • No single semantic layer. Enterprise applications today, whether SAP or non-SAP, all have differences in their data structures. Data transformation and harmonization are necessary to allow the sharing of transactional data, and for analytical processes and AI functions to  take place.
  • One-way data transformation. Data warehousing, as practiced by SAP and by other vendors in the past, focused on extraction  and one-way transformation, storage, and processing of data, decoupled from original data structures and business process context. Effective, enterprise-wide AI, however, requires two-way transformation and re-integration of data into business processes as they run.

What organizations need

AI agent networks need a solid data foundation  if they are to process queries across systems effectively. The organization’s data structures—its master data and system architecture—need to be harmonized so AI can understand the different systems in a consistent and accurate way.

When processes are integrated, consistent data can be stored in the systems. Integrating systems and maintaining consistent data will overcome the problem of isolated, fragmented systems and allow AI to execute end-to-end business processes.

 

SAP’s strategy for scalable AI

SAP’s approach to enabling organizations to scale their use of AI is to facilitate the integration of systems and business processes, and the harmonization of business data, within a secure AI architecture.

The key components of this are:

  • Secure AI architecture
  • Solutions for scaling AI
  • Joule, the integrated digital assistant
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for data harmonization
  • SAP Business Technology Platform as the platform for Joule, SAP BDC, AI Hub, and process

Secure AI architecture

Figure 1: A common sub-optimal approach

Figure 2: Exposing corporate data to LLMs is not recommended

Figure 3: How to allow AI to understand your business safely

SAP's secure architecture allows AI to understand your business safely.

The process works like this:

  • The user queries their digital assistant, Joule.
  • The digital assistant uses both the LLM and the vector database to create a refined prompt. The technical process is decoupled from the proprietary business data (a technique known as masking) to prevent the data being exposed outside the organization.
  • The refined prompt then requests data from cloud ERP and other proprietary systems, such as the  SAP Foundation Model.
  • Data is returned to the digital assistant via the vector database and the results are clustered and explained by the LLM.
  • The digital assistant then presents the final answer to the user.

 

SAP solutions for scaling AI

As an SAP customer, you may be familiar with our strategic architecture. Working from the top down, we call out here three elements which are material to scaling AI.

Figure 4: SAP strategic architecture

Joule

Joule is SAP’s agent orchestrator and ubiquitous user interface for AI. It is embedded throughout SAP Business Suite solutions incl. SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private. Joule skills perform simple repetitive tasks within one application. Joule Agents give context-aware access to a system  of AI agents, that can perform more complex end-to-end processes across multiple systems— provided those systems have been integrated and their data’s been harmonized.

Agents can work within or separately from Joule. They can call and quest other agents in the background without having to be triggered manually. This is done transparently in Joule to keep the human in the loop.

SAP Business Technology Platform

SAP Business Technology Platform supports SAP Business Suite solutions. It provides a foundation for AI and data analytics and includes integration and extension solutions.

  • SAP Integration Suite contains more than 3,800 prebuilt integrations and APIs for connecting business processes across systems more easily.
  • SAP Build solutions help you create extensions and automate processes across SAP and  non-SAP solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a single semantic layer across applications and enables the harmonization of data. This is essential not only for AI to work effectively, but also to share transactional data and facilitate analytical processes. SAP BDC uses data products which are prebuilt multi-layered structures (which may include extensions of clean-core compliant data structures) for executing function-specific queries and processes across SAP and non-SAP systems.

Having a common data platform across your enterprise allows AI to utilize your proprietary  business data within a secure environment. The data products come as part of so-called intelligent applications which contains applications built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, as well as other domain content.

Customers can always extend the data layer, for example by defining custom data products.

Advantages of SAP Business Data Cloud

In some cases, operational data has been used for executing AI functions or analytical and planning operations without applying data products from SAP BDC. In the past, data storage for these operations took place in BTP, as the AI hub is located there as well as in SAP Datasphere and SAP HANA. But what was missing was the delivery of a common and harmonized data storage concept across all SAP applications.

SAP BDC makes it possible to establish a common architecture where data is extracted, transformed, and returned to SAP Business Suite applications, creating harmonized data storage. A common data platform across your organization will provide the data foundation for AI to connect securely to specialized, enterprise-specific data.

SAP BDC also allows for SAP-managed deployment, maintenance, and facilitation of data processing and transformation from the source system to SAP BDC. These services are part of the data products of the intelligent applications.

SAP Business Suite provides APIs between different SAP and non-SAP applications, allowing the data exchange needed for integrated execution of business processes.

Prioritizing the establishment of a common layer also influences changes to local data structures. The data required to support integrated business process and other cross-system operations is held directly within the source systems, with no need for a secondary harmonization layer. This is very well aligned with the clean core concept.

 

What does it mean for me?

Do I need all this before my AI will work?

No, but the more elements you have, the more value you get.

  • If you only have SAP BDC, you’ll have access to harmonized data—but you won’t yet have connected business processes across applications.
  • If you use SAP BTP solutions such as SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build to create integrations and extensions, you’ll be able to join up business processes across applications—but not harmonize their data.
  • If you use SAP BDC and SAP BTP solutions together, you can integrate business processes across systems and harmonize their data. A derived harmonization model is intended to be generated by the system using APIs to produce a fully integrated model for cross-system reporting and AI data usage. Then Joule Agents can use that harmonized data to orchestrate end-to-end business processes across multiple systems automatically.

Are there other ways of doing this?

Yes, but they’re not as good. Some of our customers use third party data harmonization solutions for cross-system analytical use cases.

The difference with SAP’s AI-first strategy is that it is always aware of the actual business context and reintegrates results data back into the business process. This is essential if AI agents are to make use of that data in cross-department, cross-system use cases.

SAP’s integrated suite of ERP and business applications, together with our data management solution, and our integration and extension solutions, is unique in the marketplace at present.

How can I move from isolated use cases to enterprise-wide AI?

Basically, you need to offer AI that people can trust.

To achieve trust, you need a secure AI architecture along with integrated processes and harmonized data. When you have these, people will trust the AI model. Then they’ll come to view it as reliable and adopt it for day-to-day, end-to-end business processes across the organization.

 

How this approach can help you - a worked example

Automating financial close

One of the most attractive use cases for AI is to modernize a business process which occurs in every business and which, if automated, would deliver significant productivity and cost benefits. The process in question is the financial close.

It’s a classic challenge. The data required sits in multiple systems, such as ERP, CRM, tax engines, and payroll—which aren’t integrated. The data is also in incompatible formats. Both these mean that considerable manual work is required in extracting and reconciling the data. All of which adds up to time, cost, and stress at the end of every accounting period.

With systems integrated using SAP Integration Suite, and data harmonized using SAP Business Data Cloud, Joule Agents can be built to help perform financial close processes optimally—always leaving knowledgeable human beings to make the final decision.

SAP’s enablers of autonomous finance can expedite financial close processes and deliver material cost savings. The Canadian energy company, Suncor, achieved a reduction of US$20,000 in month-end closing costs and a 98% reduction in time to reconcile ICT postings using SAP Business AI and SAP Build Process Automation.

Figure 5: Integration flow diagram of a connected financial close process in SAP Integration Suite.

 

How do I get started?

To summarize, our two key recommendations are to modernize your data and integrate your processes.

Modernize your data

Evolve your data strategy from using harmonized historical data extracted from business systems, to using current data generated in the process of executing business processes.

Aim to make multiple data sources accessible to AI, including a combination of business data from multiple internal systems and external data.

Integrate your processes

Move away from older integration technologies that are not cloud aware, such as process integration or process orchestration, to standardizing on SAP Integration Suite with thousands of prebuilt integrations.

Adopt a consistent method across the organization for connecting your processes so that when you build AI agents to orchestrate them across multiple systems, users get a consistent experience.

 

Immediate next steps

Ask your SAP account manager to set up a conversation with one of our enterprise architects. You can discuss where you are now, where you want to be, and draw up a plan for getting there.

In the meantime, find out more about:

  • SAP Business Technology Platform
  • SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP’s vision for autonomous finance

entry.title: When Large XML Breaks SOAP in SAP CPI: Understanding CXF Limits, Misleading Errors, and the Real Fix
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

Recently we faced an issue: a large EPCIS payload caused CPI’s SOAP Adapter to crash with pretty technical error text:

Error Details
org.apache.camel.InvalidPayloadException: No body available of type: java.lang.String but has value: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c of type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload on: Message. Caused by: Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT. Exchange[69E7F6624A5A223-000000000000000A]. Caused by: [org.apache.camel.TypeConversionException - Error during type conversion from type: org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload to the required type: java.lang.String with value org.apache.camel.component.cxf.converter.CachedCxfPayload@22fcc44c due to java.lang.IllegalStateException: Current event not START_ELEMENT or END_ELEMENT], cause: java.lang.IllegalStateExcept...

Nothing in this exception suggests “your XML is too big” and the message was only 10M which is below default 40M SOAP Adapter max.

The Real Cause: Apache CXF XML Security Limits

CPI’s SOAP Adapter is built on Apache CXF and Apache Camel.
Before CPI ever sees the message, CXF enforces several safety thresholds:

Our EPCIS messages contained more than 100K child elements — far beyond the 50,000 limit.

Once CXF hits a threshold, it stops parsing.
Camel then tries to convert an incomplete payload into a String or DOM — and fails with a meaningless type-conversion exception.

Why You Cannot “Fix the XML”

In many regulatory or B2B integrations, the message structure is dictated by standards.
In this case, reducing batch size or restructuring XML was not feasible:
the EPCIS payloads legitimately exceeded CXF’s defaults.

So we raised an SAP ticket.

SAP’s Proposed Solution

SAP confirmed the issue and outlined the steps needed to resolve it:

  1. Provide your CPI/Integration Suite tenant URL. SAP adjusts parameters at the tenant runtime level.
  2. Specify the new maxChildElements limit. Choose a value based on your maximal observed EPCIS batch size.
  3. Approve a maintenance window for restart. SAP must restart your tenant’s processing node to activate new CXF settings. Downtime: 15–20 minutes.

💡Why a Tenant Restart Is Required — Even in a CI/CD Cloud

This is a common point of confusion.

CPI feels like a CI/CD-managed cloud service, so why does SAP need a restart? Here’s the reason in simple terms:

CPI is cloud-hosted, but each tenant still runs on Java/Camel runtimes.

When SAP changes CXF parser limits, they are modifying JVM-level runtime properties that Camel and CXF read only at startup.

Just like changing JVM memory parameters, thread pools, or parser configurations:
these cannot be hot-reloaded.

So the restart isn’t a flaw — it’s a consequence of:

  • the underlying Java processes
  • Camel routing engines
  • CXF parser initialisation

It is normal and expected behaviour

✔️Key Takeaways

  • CPI SOAP Adapter errors can be misleading when XML is too large.
  • The real limits come from Apache CXF, not SAP configuration mistakes.
  • EPCIS and similar standards may exceed maxChildElements.
  • XML cannot always be made smaller — sometimes the standard dictates structure.
  • SAP can raise limits, but must restart the tenant to apply changes.

entry.title: Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration – Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will explore the migration process of XSLT mappings.   

While SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration supports XSLT mappings, you may encounter subtle yet impactful differences when migrating XSLT-based mappings from SAP Process Orchestration (PO). This post outlines the main variations between both environments, explains typical runtime issues, and provides practical guidance for smooth adaptation.

 

XSLT Processor Differences 

The XSLT processor behind Cloud Integration is Saxon EE 9.9.1.6 (as of November 2025 – see this Blog for details on verifying the processor version) while SAP Process Orchestration next to its default allowed the import and use of other processors. 

While these differences should not usually cause major compatibility problems, certain manual adjustments after the tool-assisted migration might be required to deploy or execute mappings successfully. In particular, there are variations in how standard XSLT functions handle data types, how Java classes are used within XSLT code and how other stylesheets are included. 

 

Data Type Handling in XSLT Functions 

SAP Process Orchestration tends to be more lenient regarding data type usage in standard XSLT functions. Cloud Integration, on the other hand, applies stricter type validation during compilation and runtime. 

Example 1: Using xsl:sort with Data Types 

The xsl:sort function sorts data based on specified criteria: 

<xsl:sort select="data" data-type="text"/> 

The allowed data types for this function are "text" and "number". On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:sort select="DATES" order="ascending" data-type="xsd:Date"/> 

However, in Cloud Integration this causes a runtime error: 

Adjusting the data-type accordingly to text or number solves this issue. However, one needs to pay attention to the effects this might have on the format and thus the rest of the stylesheet execution. 

 

Example 2: Using format-number() with non-numeric inputs 

On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(substring(data, 0, 3), '0.00')"/> 

In Cloud Integration, this causes a compilation error during runtime: 

The issue arises because format-number() requires a numeric input, while substring() returns a string. 
To resolve this, explicitly convert the substring to a number: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(number(substring(data, 0, 3)), '0.00')"/> 

Please note that if a global number format is defined, this conversion might affect the formatting of the substring according to that global setting. 

 

Using Java Classes in XSLT 

XSLT mappings sometimes rely on custom Java classes to extend the functionality of native XSLT functions, a common practice in integration projects where XSLT offered fewer built-in capabilities.  

During migration, you may encounter Java classes ranging from simple helpers (e.g., string or date transformations, counters) to more complex ones (e.g., document loaders, RFC calls, or value mapping lookups). While some advanced use cases may require redesign or alternative approaches, simpler helper classes can still be used in Cloud Integration. 

Step 1: Uploading the Java Classes 

Upload the Java classes as a JAR file and add them to the iFlow’s References (using the Archive option).
