Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Introduction: Why Extensibility Matters in EHS Implementations

Implementing SAP Environment, Health & Safety (EHS) in the Public Cloud provides customers with a powerful set of standard capabilities across EHS functionality such as Incident Management, Risk Management, or Emissions Management. However, real-life EHS processes often include country-specific regulations, industry-dependent reporting obligations, and customer-individual workflows that cannot always be covered by the standard product alone. This is where extensibility becomes a critical success factor.

From our project experience, we see that nearly every EHS implementation requires selected adaptations – whether to incorporate local legal requirements, enrich analytics, adjust incident forms, or create custom validations. With SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP EHS, such enhancements must follow SAP’s clean-core principles, meaning they must be implemented using the officially supported extensibility technologies.

This blog post provides a clear, practical overview of the extensibility options available for SAP EHS in the Public Cloud and demonstrates how they can be applied to real-world scenarios.

1.1 What You Can Expect from This Blog Post

In this part, we outline the extensibility landscape for EHS Public Cloud and guide you through:

  • Which extensibility options exist in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • How they apply specifically to EHS use cases
  • Which BAdIs are available and when to use them
  • Concrete examples for extensibility
  • Best practices based on our project experience

The aim is to give implementation teams a practical understanding of how to adapt the system without breaking the clean core, ensuring long-term upgradeability and compliance.

1.2 Why Extensibility is Especially Important for EHS

From our project experience, EHS is one of the most extensibility-driven domains in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud because:

  • Regulations differ significantly by country (e.g. OSHA, EU directives, etc.)
  • Incident reports must reflect local legal requirements
  • Customers require tailored analytics and KPIs
  • Integration with external safety systems is common
  • Forms and regulatory outputs often need custom structures

EHS processes must adapt to organizational legal, and operational needs. Extensibility in Public Cloud ensures this adaptability without compromising SAP’s clean-core principles.

 

2. Extensibility Options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides a comprehensive extensibility portfolio designed to support innovation without compromising the stability of the core system. These capabilities range from low-code configuration tools for business users to pro-code development environments for technical teams. Understanding these options is essential for designing scalable, future-proof EHS solutions – especially in Public Cloud environments where clean-core principles are mandatory.

Extensibility Portfolio for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Own illustration based on SAP source: https://www.sap.com/documents/2018/05/606d1ee8-037d-0010-87a3-c30de2ffd8ff.html)

2.1 Low-Code vs. Pro-Code Extensibility

The extensibility portfolio is structured along two axes:

  • Low-Code: Target at key user and functional experts who need to quickly adapt user interfaces, create fields, or adjust logic without deep technical development.
  • Pro-Code: Designed for professional developers who require advanced capabilities through the ABAP Cloud development model or SAP BTP services.

These options are distributed across two major extensibility categories: On-Stack Extensibility (In-App) & Side-by-Side Extensibility.

2.2 On-Stack Extensibility (In-App)

Executed directly inside SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, following the clean-core principles enforced by SAP.

Key User & Developer Extensibility

2.2.1 Key User Extensibility (Low-Code)

Accessible directly via the SAP Fiori Launchpad, key user extensibility enables business focused adjustments such as:

  • UI adaptation mode: Modify screen layouts, hide/show fields, rearrange sections.
  • Custom fields: Create and publish custom fields that automatically extend UI, APIs, CDS views, and reports.
  • Custom logic (using BAdIs or BDEF extensions): Implement small logic enhancements using predefined extensions points.
  • Custom business objects: Model simple new business objects without coding.
  • Custom CDS views & OData services: Build analytical and integration-ready views with drag-and-drop tooling.
  • Analytical queries and applications: Extend reporting and KPIs in SAP Fiori or SAP Analytics Cloud.

Key User Extensibility is ideal for EHS teams that need to adapt processes quickly, e.g. adding a regulatory field in Incident Management or creating country-specific reporting structures.

2.2.2 Developer Extensibility (Pro-Code)

Developer Extensibility is performed using ABAP Cloud in Eclipse via ABAP Development Tools (ADT), enabling professional developers to build upgrade-safe extensions inside the SAP S/4HANA Cloud stack.

Typical capabilities include:

  • UI adaptation projects via SAP Business Application Studio
  • Extension fields built using professional ABAP development tools
  • Custom logic (BAdIs and BDEF extensions) with advanced editor capabilities
  • RAP Business Objects (full-fledge RESTful ABAP applications)
  • CDS views and OData services with full development tooling
  • Analytical queries and custom analytical content

This level of extensibility is used when EHS implementations require more complex data models, multi-step validations, or custom processes beyond the key user scope.

2.3 Side-by-Side Extensibility

When requirements cannot be fulfilled within the S/4HANA Cloud stack, SAP BTP provides a powerful platform for building complementary applications:

  • SAP Build Apps (no-code mobile and web apps)
  • SAP Build Process Automation (workflows and automations)
  • SAP Build Work Zone (custom dashboard and portals)
  • SAP Build Code / CAP (cloud-native pro-code development, Node.js/Java)
  • ABAP Environment on BTP (Steampunk) for ABAP Cloud side-by-side extensions

Side-by-side extensibility is particularly relevant for EHS when:

  • complex mobile solutions are required (e.g. hazard observations, audits)
  • workflow automation or robotic processing is desired
  • large-scale integration scenarios (e.g., IoT sensors, safety systems) are needed
  • custom employee or contractor portals must be built

Although side-by-side extensibility plays an important role in the overall SAP extensibility strategy, we will not dive deeper into BTP-based extensions in this blog post. Our objective is to demonstrate what can be achieved directly within the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, using standard in-app extensibility options that remain fully aligned with SAP’s clean-core principles. Based on our project experience, most EHS related enhancements such as custom fields, logic, reporting extensions, and form adaptations can be delivered efficiently using Key User or Developer Extensibility (on-stack). For this reason, the upcoming chapters focus exclusively on in-app, upgrade-safe extensibility scenarios that can be implemented without additional BTP architecture.

2.4 BAdIs in the Public Cloud (Key User vs. Developer Access)

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) are predefined extension points provided by SAP that allow injecting custom logic while staying upgrade safe. You can explore the available BAdIs for the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here: Business Add-Ins | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

There are two categories in S/4HANA Public Cloud:

Key User BAdIs

  • Implemented through the Custom Logic SAP Fiori app
  • Available only for selected business contexts
  • Designed for simple enhancements such as: Validation rules, Derivation of field values, Basic calculations

Developer BAdIs

  • Implemented using ABAP Development Tools (ADT) in SAP BTP ABAP Environment or Embedded Steampunk
  • Allow more complex coding scenarios
  • Enable interaction with APIs, CDS views, RAP BOs and advanced data handling

In EHS specifically, SAP provides a growing set of BAdIs – particularly in Incident Management and Emissions Management – which are essential for country specific reporting, custom form generation, or regulatory compliance.

The following list provides an overview of the EHS-specific BAdIs that are currently available in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Incident Management

  • BAdI: Change of Field Values in BG (Berufsgenossenschaft) Incident Report (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Basic Information (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Custom Field Incident Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Involved Person Data (Key User)
  • BAdI: Retrieval of Incident Root Data (Key User)

Risk Management

  • (No BAdIs available for Risk Management in Public Cloud yet)

Emissions Management

  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Amount Root (Key User)
  • BAdI: Check Amounts State and Perform Subsequent Actions (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Generation of Export Files (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Compliance Requirement Import from XLSX (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection Import from XLSX BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Automatic Data Collection XLSX Parser BAdI (Key User & Developer)
  • BAdI: Field Control for Extension of Data Collection Root (Key User)

As the overview shows, the currently available BAdIs for EHS in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud are primarily focused on Key User Extensibility, especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management. While Developer Extensibility via ABAP Cloud provides a more advanced pro-code extension model, the current EHS-specific enhancement points are mostly delivered as in-app, low-code BAdIs to ensure upgrade stability and full alignment with SAP’s clean core principles.

This corresponds closely with our experience from project implementations: Most EHS extension requirements can be delivered efficiently using in-app, Key User Extensibility tools such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, UI Adaptation, and CDS View extensions without requiring developer access.

 

3. Practical Extensibility Scenarios in EHS

In chapter 2, we explored the extensibility options available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and outlined which of these options are most relevant for EHS implementations. As highlighted, the majority of extensibility points currently exposed in the EHS area (especially within Incident Management and Emissions Management) are implemented using Key User Extensibility, including custom fields, UI adaptation, form template configuration, and Custom Logic BAdIs.

Because of this, this chapter focuses exclusively on Key User Extensibility in practice, demonstrating how customers can solve real-world EHS requirements entirely within the Public Cloud without requiring developer extensibility or SAP BTP side-by-side extensions.

Drawing from our project experience, we selected two scenarios that reflect common customer requirements:

  1. Adding custom attributes to the Incident Management process
  2. Generating a country-specific incident report, using custom form templates and multiple BAdIs

Both scenarios illustrate how far customers can go using the extensibility tools embedded in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, while fully adhering to the clean-core principle.

3.1 Example 1 - Introducing a Custom Attribute for Incident Records

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Custom Fields App (SAP Fiori App)
  • UI Adaptation (SAP Fiori Settings)

3.1.1 Business Requirement

Many organizations require an additional field “Business Unit” to be captured as part of incident documentation to meet internal reporting needs, support organizational analysis, or fulfill local compliance requirements. Since this information is not available in the standard SAP EHS Public Cloud data model, customers often need to introduce it as a custom field.

Typically, the Business Unit may be required in multiple stages of the Incident Management process, such as:

  • Incident Creation
  • Incident Processing
  • Reporting and Analytics Dashboards

In our case, the Business Unit field was only added to the Incident Processing step, primarily for simplicity and to demonstrate the extensibility approach in clear and focused manner. However, this field can be added to additional UIs and process steps as needed, depending on the customer’s specific requirements, organizational structure, or compliance obligations.

3.1.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Create New Custom Field

In this step a custom field for the Incident Management will be created using the “Custom Fields” Fiori App. You can follow the steps below to create a custom field:

1. Navigate to the “Custom Fields” app from the Fiori Launchpad.

2. Click “Create”.

3. Enter the following details:

  • Business Context: Select the relevant context (e.g. EHHSS_INC_BINFA).
  • Label: Provide a meaningful name (Business Unit). Identifier & Tooltip will be filled automatically.
  • Type: Choose from options like Text, Number, Date, etc.
  • Length: Define the size of the field if applicable.

Create New Field

After the required details have been filled, select Create and Edit.

4. Enable the fields for the relevant applications.

The fields of the tabs User Interfaces, Analytics and APIs will be enabled by default. These tabs are required to support user interactions, reporting as well as integrations for the recently added custom field (Business Unit).

Field Enablement

If the new field should appear in generated documents such as PDFs or reports, you need to enable the required Form Templates. In our scenario, two Form Templates were activated as shown below.

Enabled Form Templates

Note: The YY1_WHS_FORM10 Template is a custom Form Template. The creation of this Form Template will be shown in chapter 3.2.

5. Save and publish the custom field to make it available in the system.

 

Assign custom field to Fiori app

Custom fields created by using the “Custom Fields” Fiori app can be assigned to the relevant Fiori applications based on the selected business context. Follow these steps to add the field:

1. Open the “Manage Incident” Fiori app & click on any incident.

2. Click on your profile & choose “Adapt UI”

Navigate to "Adapt UI"

 3. Once Adapt UI is activated, you can start customizing the page layout and add the recently created custom field to the relevant sections. By selecting “Customize” > “Show Customizable Areas” as shown below, you will be able to insert the new custom field “Business Unit” into the desired section of the Fiori App.

Navigate to "Show Customizable Areas"

 4. Select the Customizable Area that should be changed.

Select Customizable Area

 5. Select the element as shown below & click on “Customize UIBB”.

Select "Customize UIBB"

 6. To add the new field, select “Element” > “Add Element”.

Add Element

 7. Select the recently created field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN and select “OK”.

Select field YY1_BUSINESSUNIT_IBN

 

In the below shown illustration you can see an example, after the Business Unit was added to the UI.

Field Business Unit added to UI

 8. Save the UI adaptation for this page.  

 

3.2 Example 2 - Generating a Country-Specific Incident Report

Extensibility Type:

  • Key User Extensibility

Tools & Apps Used:

  • Adobe Lifecycle Designer (External Tool)
  • Maintain Form Template App (SAP Fiori App)
  • Custom Logic App (SAP Fiori App)
  • CBC Configuration (SAP Public Cloud) / or if no access exists Implementation Activities (SAP Fiori App)

3.2.1 Business Requirement

In many EHS implementations, customers need to generate country-specific incident reports that comply with national legal requirements. These reports often require a combination of standard fields, people related information, and custom fields that are not provided in the SAP EHS Public Cloud standard forms. For example, organizations operating in Australia may be required to submit the WHS Form 10, a mandatory workplace health and safety report documenting incidents, injuries, or hazards in accordance with the Australian Work Health and Safety (WHS) Regulations (made-up). To support this requirement, a custom Adobe form template must be created and populated with incident data, including custom fields. This requires implementing the relevant Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) to retrieve, map, and supply the correct incident information into the custom form.

The report must include:

  • Basic incident details
  • Person and involvement information
  • Custom fields required for the local legislative format

3.2.2 Step-by-Step Implementation

Develop a Custom Form in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

A custom form template needs to be created to meet the specific requirements of the report. The form should include all necessary fields. To showcase this example, we created the form template YY1_WHS_FORM10 in Adobe Lifecycle Designer and saved it as an xdp file.

Form Template Creation in Adobe Lifecycle Designer

 

Upload Custom Form in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Once the custom form template is created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer, the next step is to upload it to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by using the “Maintain Form Template” app.

1. Open the “Maintain Form Template” app in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

2. Navigate to the “Custom Template” tab.

3. Click “New” to create a new entry.

4. Enter a Form Template Name of your choice (for example “YY1_WHS_FORM10” including the prefix “YY1_” for custom forms).

5. Upload the form file that you created in Adobe Lifecycle Designer.

6. Select the Data Source Name as “EHSS_FDP_INCIDENT_SRV”.

The illustration below shows how the form setup was done in our scenario.

Form Setup (1)

Form Setup (2)

 

Assign Custom Fields & Custom Logic to the form

In this step we assign the created custom fields & logic to the form (shown in the previous step). This is achieved by using the “Custom Logic” app in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where you can leverage the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) provided by the system. To retrieve the required information in the form, you can implement the following BAdIs:

  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PERS
  • BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

1. Click “Create” to start a new implementation.

2. Select one of the mentioned BAdIs above and proceed to “Step 2” (if no filters are needed jump over to step 3 and enter an Implementation Description).

3. Create and publish the Implementation.

4. Navigate to the created Implementation.

Created Implementations

 5. Select “Code Editor” and write ABAP logic using released APIs and CDS views.

Open Code Editor

The below shown BAdI implementation YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO retrieves incident basic information from the CDS View I_IncidentBasicInfo and populates the INCIDENTBASICINFO structure, so that key fields such as the Creation Date Time or Business Unit (which was previously created as a custom field in chapter 3.1) are available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_BASIC_INFO

Perform the same steps for the other required BadIs.

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE retrieves involved person details, such as Person’s Full Name, from the CDS View I_IncidentInvolvedPerson which makes it available in the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_INVOLVED_PE

BAdI YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT retrieves root-level incident data such as CreationDateTime from the CDS View I_Incident and makes these fields available for the custom form.

YY1_BADI_EHHSS_INC_ROOT

Note: BAdIs are essential because they supply data for custom and standard fields in the form. Without these implementations, the fields would remain empty, as the standard logic does not retrieve the required CDS view information.

6. Click “Publish” to implement.

 

Functional Configuration (Assign Form to regulation)

Uploading the Adobe form just makes the template available in the system. To actually use it in the EHS process, you need to specify the form and assign it to the correct form group and regulation. This ensures the form is linked to the appropriate compliance context and can be selected when generating reports.

This can be achieved by performing the mentioned steps below performed in the SAP Central Business Configuration (or ”Implementation Activities” app).

1. Specify form: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Forms

Each form entry shows key technical attributes:

  • Form Name & Form Title : Represents the form to be specified (In our scenario: WHS).
  • Form Type: Indicates the technology used for the form. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, this is typically “SAP Interactive Form”, which refers to Adobe-based forms used for output and reporting.
  • Form Controller: Controls the rendering and behavior of the form in SAP (In our scenario: CL_EHFND_FW_ADS_OM_FORM_CTRL).
  • Data Provider: Supplies the data from the EHS process to the form (In our scenario: CL_EHHSS_AIF_INCIDENT_DPROV).
  • Form Object Name: Identifies the form template used for output. This should match the custom form you uploaded earlier in the “Maintain Form Template” app (In our scenario: YY1_WHS_FORM10).

Specify Form

 2. Assign Form to the Form Group: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration  > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Specify Form Groups and Assign Forms

Assign Form to Form Group (1)

After defining the form groups, the next step is to assign the relevant specified forms to these groups. This can be performed on the second level of the selected form group and ensures that the custom or standard forms are correctly linked to the appropriate reporting or regulatory context.

Assign Form to Form Group (2)

 3. Specify Regulations & assign Regulation to Incidents: Select one of the mentioned apps above and navigate to SAP Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety >  Specify Regulations.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (1)

After specifying the regulation (e.g., WHS), the next step is to assign it to the relevant incident categories. This ensures that when users select a regulation in the Incident process, the correct forms from the assigned form group become available for reporting.

Specify Regulations & Assign Regulation to Incidents (2)

 4. Assign the Forms to Regulations: Finally, link the forms to the corresponding regulation. This step ensures that when a regulation (e.g., WHS) is selected in the Incident process, the correct form becomes available for reporting.

Therefore, open the SAP Central Business Configuration > Compliance and Trade > Environment, Health, and Safety > Assign Forms to Regulations.

Assign Forms to Regulations

 

Generating the Report

Once the configuration is complete, you can generate the report directly from the “Manage Incident” app.

1. Open the “Manage Incident” app

2. Select any Incident which has the status  “In Process”.

3. Click on “Regulations”, choose “WHS”, then click “OK” and” Save”.

Generate Report (1)

After selecting the WHS regulation, the system makes the corresponding report option available under the “Reports” tab.

4. Navigate to the “Reports” tab.

5. Select the WHS Report from the list.

6. Click “Generate” to create the report.

Generate Report (2)

Once you click “Generate” for the selected Report Type, the WHS report is created and appears in the list as a downloadable PDF.

Generate Report (3)

The final output reflects all required incident details, including custom and standard fields, in the WHS Form 10 format.

Output

 

4. Summary & Lessons Learned

Extensibility plays a critical role in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementations for Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS). As demonstrated throughout this blog post, even highly regulated processes such as incident reporting or country-specific compliance documentation can be effectively supported using SAP’s clean-core extensibility framework.

Drawing from our project experience and the two practical use cases presented, this chapter summarizes the key takeaways and highlights the most important lessons learned when implementing extensibility in EHS Public Cloud.

4.1 Key Takeaways

Clean-Core Extensibility Is Not a Limitation – It is a Design Principle

The SAP Public Cloud model enforces strict boundaries around what can be extended. Rather than restricting customers, these boundaries ensure:

  • Long-term upgrade protection
  • Predictable lifecycle behavior
  • Lower maintenance effort
  • Full SAP supportability

All enhancements must therefore rely on SAP-released extension points.

Most EHS Requirements Can Be Solved with Key User Extensibility

A major insight from our implementations is that the majority of EHS use cases do not require developer extensibility or side-by-side applications.

Key User tools already cover:

  • Custom data fields
  • UI adaptations
  • PDF report adjustments
  • BAdI logic

Both examples in this blog were fully implemented using Key User Extensibility only.

BAdIs Are the Backbone of EHS Extensibility

SAP delivers a growing catalogue of EHS specific BAdIs in the Public Cloud, particularly for:

  • Incident Management
  • Emissions Management

Key lessons:

  • Each BAdI is designed for a very specific business context.
  • You often need to use several BAdIs together to populate a report for a form.
  • They enable retrieving structured data via released CDS Views and APIs.
  • Clean and modular implementations significantly improve maintainability.

Custom Forms Require a Structured Approach

Regulatory reports require a combination of:

  • A form template (Adobe)
  • Custom fields
  • BAdI logic
  • CBC configuration

The lesson: Form extensibility is not only a technical activity – it is a cross-functional exercise involving business, logic, and configuration layers.

Configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) / Implementation Activities is Essential

EHS reporting relies heavily on CBC / Implementation Activities, especially when assigning:

  • Forms > form groups
  • Form groups > regulations
  • Regulations > incident categories

A common project challenge: Without correct CBC (or Implementation Activities) configuration, even perfectly implemented forms and BAdIs will not appear in the UI.

End-to-End Testing Is Crucial

Because EHS extensions span UI, logic, reporting and configuration layers, testing must always validate the entire lifecycle:

  • Incident creation > processing > regulation selection > report generation

This avoids fragmented testing and ensures that all extension layers work together seamlessly.

4.2 Lessons Learned

Start With the Simplest Possible Extension Option

Always begin with Key User tools before considering Developer Extensibility or SAP BTP. Public Cloud projects succeed when complexity is added only where absolutely necessary.

Choose BAdIs Wisely – Don’t Over-Engineer

Each BAdI serves a narrow purpose. Trying to force a single BAdI to solve multiple needs often causes issues later. Modular, purpose-aligned implementations are easier to maintain and debug.

Document Custom Logic and Configuration Thoroughly

Because Public Cloud enforces strict structure, even small enhancements should be:

  • Named consistently (YY1_*)
  • Documented cleanly (purpose, input, output)
  • Readable for team members who join the project later.

Well-documented extensions also reduce future rework during audits or regulatory updates.

Maintain a Strong Governance Around Extensibility

Typical governance measures include:

  • Reviewing whether a need truly requires an extension
  • Maintaining a central register of custom fields and BAdIs
  • Ensuring no duplicate fields are created
  • Enforcing naming conventions

This prevents uncontrolled growth of extensions over time.

Engage Business Users Early in the Design Process

EHS professionals often know exactly how regulations should be represented. Early involvement helps:

  • Avoid unnecessary extensions
  • Validate report layouts
  • Confirm the accuracy of populated data
  • Ensure usability in real operational scenarios

Plan for Future Regulatory Requirements

EHS compliance evolves frequently. When building extensions, always think ahead:

  • Could this field or form be reused for another regulation?
  • Can we structure the logic to accommodate more categories in the future?
  • Are we using modular BAdI implementations that can scale?

This significantly reduces technical dept.

4.3 Best Practices

To close this chapter, here is a consolidated best-practice checklist:

  • Use SAP-released extension points only (clean core).
  • Prefer Key User Extensibility for EHS whenever possible.
  • Keep BAdI implementations modular and business-context specific.
  • Use functional naming conventions for fields, forms, and BAdIs.
  • Perform end-to-end lifecycle testing (UI > logic > form > CBC).
  • Document every extension early, including purpose and data sources.
  • Reuse released CDS Views and APIs – never rely on unreleased objects.
  • Involve business users early to ensure regulatory accuracy.
  • Build form templates in a future-proof, scalable structure.
  • Maintain strong governance to avoid unnecessary or duplicate extensions.

4.4 Final Remark

Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is not about pushing technical boundaries. It is about using the right tools to deliver business value while protecting system integrity. With a structured approach, as illustrated in both examples, customers can achieve regulatory compliance, process optimization, and system flexibility without compromising the clean-core principles that define the Public Cloud.

entry.title: Public Cloud Internal Supplier Integration with EDI
entry.content:
Introduction

The traditional IDoc structure and the process of posting offsetting (clearing) incoming invoices, which have been used for years in on-premise systems, have significantly evolved in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. With the introduction of standardized communication arrangements in the Public Cloud, EDI integrations are now utilized more actively and efficiently.

For instance, in on-premise environments, I have implemented the offsetting invoice posting process using the RD04 invoice output for many years. However, this approach is being replaced in the cloud with more integrated and automated communication frameworks.

1         Prerequisites

For EDI Output, 2EL scopes and for EDI Input, 2EJ scopes must be activated.

To configure the EDI integration, users require the following business roles in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR)
  • Business Integration Expert (SAP_BR_CONF_EXPERT_BUS_NET_INT)
  • Master Data Specialist (SAP_BR_BUPA_MASTER_SPECIALIST)

2         Preparation

This document describes additional configuration steps that must be carried out by customers to activate the Integration of Sales with External Buyers (2EL) and Procurement with External Suppliers (2EJ) scope item. Since these configuration steps are customer-specific, they can't be delivered by SAP.

3         Business Partners

Table for Organization

 

Buyer Company (Purchase Process)

Supplier Company (Sales Process)

Company Code

17US

10US

Partner

1000000 10US Company Partner

36100002 17US Company Partner

First, a business partner is created for the supplier company code and expanded to the purchasing company code.

Next, a partner is created for the purchasing company code and expanded to the supplier company code. During this expansion, the supplier business partner number is entered as a 10-character number in the Account at Customer field within the relevant business partner.

4         Configuration

4.1      Assign Tax Code

The tax rate to be used in the purchase invoice is determined for the tax indicator in the incoming requests.

İmplementation Activities: Procurement -> Invoice Management -> Communication for Invoice Management -> Assign Tax Codes for the Transfer of Supplier Invoices

4.2      Program Parameters

In Configure Program Parameters, you specify the required program parameter configuration IDs. Each ID contains the relevant program parameters for posting a supplier invoice.

İmplementation Activities: Procurement -> Invoice Management -> Communication for Invoice Management -> Configure and assign program parameters

Assign Program Parameters

In Assign Program Parameters, the generated Parameter ID is assigned to the supplier. This determines which parameter a supplier will proceed with.

4.3      Assign Company Code

In the requests, the company code name determines which company code will be used to create the relevant purchase invoice.

Note: The Company Code Name here represents the Payer addressee on the sales invoice.

4.4      Communications

A User to be used in integrations is created within the Maintain Communication Users app.

A new system is created within the Communication System app. This system will contain information about the system that will communicate.

Enter the user created above in the Inbound User and Outbound User sections. In the Business Partners section, the important point here is to enter the relevant paying partner number.

Following the sales invoice, the SAP_COM_0223 scenario is created for the SAP system exit phase. The previously created System is assigned to this scenario.

In our structure, we will use the SAP_COM_0223 scenario for the Customer Invoice service, but I am sharing other paths for the services below so that they can be used in other integrations where they are stored as desired.

  • Sales Order/Customer Return - Confirm Processing (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/orderconfirmationrequest_in

  • Outbound Delivery - Notify (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/deliveryrequest_in

  • Customer Invoice - Send (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/invoicerequest_in

To ensure that incoming requests are entered into the SAP system, the SAP_COM_0224 scenario is created. The relevant system, System, is assigned to this scenario, which is the default system on the Communication System screen.

The path to be entered for the Purchase Order - Send, Update, Cancel Service is as follows.

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/orderrequest_in

4.5      Reports and Logs

Using Fiori Launchpad, users can assign relevant EDI scenarios within the Assign Recipients to Users app, ensuring that only designated users can monitor their EDI logs.

The /SDEDI namespace must be added for EDI outputs and the /MMEDI namespace for EDI inputs.

EDI requests can be tracked within the Message Dashboard app.

Conclusion

The transition from traditional IDoc-based processes in on-premise systems to modern communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, represents a significant advancement in the way EDI integrations are handled. By leveraging standardized communication arrangements such as SAP_COM_0223 and SAP_COM_0224, organizations can achieve streamlined and automated invoice processing between sales and procurement processes.

This document has outlined the essential prerequisites, business partner configurations, and system communication settings required to enable seamless integration between external buyers and suppliers using scope items 2EL and 2EJ. Through proper assignment of tax codes, program parameters, and communication users, businesses can ensure accurate and efficient invoice exchange across systems.

  1. User should have “Application Administrator” and “Application developer” role in Microsoft Azure.

  2. Register a new application using the Azure portal.

  3. Create client credentials.

  4. Set API permissions and grant admin consent.

  5. Determine Redirect url.

  6. Make a request to Azure Active Directory authentication service using HTTP POST with a client ID and client secret to retrieve an access token.

  7. Use the access token to make HTTP requests to Microsoft Graph REST API.

Refer below Blog for the Configuration:

Cloud Integration Steps:

Step 1: Create OAuth2 Client Credentials to connect with Microsoft 365 Outlook

Go to Monitor – Manage Security - click on Create and choose “OAuth2 Client Credentials”



Provide a meaningful name for the credential “Name”

Select “Grant Type”, “Client Authentication”, “Content Type” from the drop down available in the configuration based on the requirement.

Enter the “Token Service URL”, “Client ID”, “Client Secret” and “Scope” from Microsoft app and click on deploy.

Now your credential is ready to be used in HTTP Receiver Adapter configuration in the IFlow.

Step 2: Create a Artifact/ IFlow

Go to Design- Integrations and APIs – create a Package – create an Artifact – Click on Add button and create an Integration Flow.

Start with Start Timer for the scheduler and create a Content Modifier to set up Content Type and Grant type.

Step 3: Connect with HTTP Receiver Adapter to call Microsoft Graph API

Enter REST API url in the address to read Outlook email

Select Method GET to extract the Inbox email.

Authentication: Select OAuth2 Client Credentials

Credential Name : Enter the name which was created in the Security Material.

Save and deploy. Now we can see the connectivity between Microsoft 365 Outlook and CPI is successful and able to extract data.

Convert this payload from JSON to xml.

Step 4: To get the attachment details from the read email.

Create a content modifier and set up a property to store "MessageID" which was received in the previous output data.

Create a request reply and connect to HTTP receiver adapter and call the "MessageID" in the url to get the attachment details.

Convert this payload from JSON to xml.

Step 5: To get the PDF attachment from the email.

Create a Content modifier to store a “id” value which was received from previous step.

Connect with HTTP receiver adapter again and call the exchange property “MessageID & ValueID” in the address url query to get attachment.

Scenario 1: After "Step 5" once you deploy the IFlow,  we will get the attachment of email and that can be placed in SFTP Folder with the same format.

Scenario 2: If you wanted to extract the content from the PDF attachment - After "Step 5", create a Groovy with below groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import java.util.HashMap;
// package org.apache.pdfbox.examples.util;
import org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument
import org.apache.pdfbox.util.PDFTextStripper

public static String readFromPDF(InputStream input){
        PDDocument pd;
        try {
            pd = PDDocument.load(input);
            PDFTextStripper stripper = new PDFTextStripper();
            stripper.setStartPage(1); // Start Page
//          stripper.setEndPage(1); // End Page
            String text = stripper.getText(pd);
            if (pd != null) {
                pd.close();
            }
            return text.toString()
        } catch (Exception e){
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
        return null
    }

def Message processData(Message message) {
        def body = message.getBody();
        InputStream IS = body;
        String res = readFromPDF(IS)

    message.setBody(res);
    return message;
}

After creating a Groovy script, download the "pdfbox" and "fontbox" from the below link and upload the JAR file in the Reference tab of your iFlow.

  • Download the pdfbox JAR file from the following link.
  • Download the fontbox JAR file from the following link.

Scenario 3: If you wanted to get whole email content along with attachment.

After "Step 3" - Create a content modifier and set up a property to store "MessageID" value.

Create a request reply and connect to HTTP receiver adapter by calling the exchange property "MessageID" in the url along with “$value”.

If you wanted to encode the received data from the above query, use "BASE64 Encode" to send encoded payload to respective receiver system.

entry.title: Espresso bites – Clean core Integration based on an OData example for SAP AIF monitoring
entry.content:
By Robert Schilling & Bertrand Henkel.

As an Enterprise Architect for SAP RISE customers, we guide organizations through business transformation and cloud adoption. The core integration principle enables hybrid architecture scenarios developed by SAP for customers with large and complex SAP landscapes integrating essential elements and enabling a phased transition to the cloud.

For an initial introduction to clean core principles, we recommend the following learning resource: Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Here, we demonstrate how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP systems to maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. The course is designed for beginners, takes two hours, and is free of charge.

In general clean core integration focusses on four pillars – please follow up with the official documentation or other blog entries like Future-Proofing Enterprise Agility with SAP Integration Suite and Clean Core Principles

Technically speaking the clean core integration principle focusses on these main components:

  • Establishing an API-led strategy and event driven architecture
  • SAP Integration Suite on SAP BTP,
  • Enabling operational excellence for end-to-end monitoring using
    • the Integration & Exception Monitoring capability of SAP Cloud Application Lifecycle Management (SAP Cloud ALM).
    • The monitoring capability of SAP Application Interface Framework (SAP AIF) on SAP S/4HANA,
    • The monitoring capabilities of SAP Integration Suite on SAP BTP

Based on SAP progress, many integration scenarios are already available within this solution architecture: In our daily business as Enterprise Architects we are often asked: “How do I activate these SAP standard scenarios?” and “What should I consider for my custom-built interfaces?”

Therefore, this blog focuses on the reference architecture for the monitoring capabilities for OData Services of SAP Application Interface Framework following the clean core integration principle.

 How do I activate SAP AIF Monitoring & Error Handling for SAP standard interfaces for SAP CALM integration?

To do this, the corresponding SAP AIF scenario must be activated. In the SAP documentation (see example: Purchase Requisition – OData V2) for each interface, the available AIF scenario is listed, which can then be activated using the transaction "AIF Content Transport – Deploy /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT".

If SAP standard interfaces are not listed as a scenario, SAP asks you to submit a corresponding SAP Customer Influence Request for the relevant interface, like other clean core topics. In general, you can also check the table /AIF/ICD_DATA, which underlies the transaction /AIF/CONTENT_EXTRACT.

In the meantime - How to handle SAP Standard Interfaces, where no SAP AIF Scenario is available?

At present, not all SAP Standard OData Interfaces—such as those from the Maintenance Management area—come with available SAP AIF Scenarios. So, what’s the approach for enabling SAP Cloud ALM Integration and Exception Monitoring in these cases?

These specific SAP Standard Interfaces are handled through SAP Gateway functionalities. You can monitor them directly in SAP S/4HANA using the SAP Gateway Performance Monitor (/IWFND/MONITOR) and review issues in the SAP Gateway Error Logs (/IWFND/ERROR_LOG). Currently, with SAP Cloud ALM, only data from the Error Log can be transferred to SAP Cloud ALM Integration & Exception Monitoring. For more details, please refer to the following section: Enable SAP ABAP Gateway Errors for SAP Cloud ALM.

License requirement for using SAP AIF with custom-developed interfaces:

As described in SAP Note 2293938 – License Check for SAP Application Interface Framework and in the SAP blog "SAP Application Interface Framework – Licensing", a separate SAP AIF license is required to manage custom-developed interfaces via SAP AIF. After purchasing the SAP AIF license, the AIF component AIF_GEN can be installed in the system and used for developing custom interfaces under SAP AIF. The necessary configuration steps for custom interfaces can be found in the relevant SAP help for SAP AIF interface development.

Further information:

  • Managing SAP Application Interface Framework
  • Modernizing Integration with SAP Integration Suite
  • Operating with SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook (Part 6)
entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 6: Summary & Outlook

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Summary
  • 2. Benefits & Pitfalls
  • 2.1 Benefits
  • 2.2 Pitfalls
  • 2.3 Summary of Benefits & Pitfalls
  • 3. Outlook
  • 4. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Summary

 

In this blog series, we shared our hands-on experience from multiple SAP EHS Public Cloud projects that were implemented in a hybrid, side-by-side landscape. Across Parts 1 to 5, we covered the integration of Employees, Business Partners, Materials, Functional Locations, and Equipment, as well as practical extensibility scenarios from real customer use cases.

What became very clear throughout these projects is that SAP EHS Public Cloud works best when three things come together:

  • Consistent master data,
  • Standardized integration content,
  • And a disciplined clean-core extensibility strategy.

In practice, we saw that missing or inconsistent master data was the most common root cause for broken end-to-end EHS processes (far more critical than any technical limitation). Once HR data, business partners, materials and assets were properly aligned across systems, incident reporting, emissions calculations, and follow-up processes became significantly more stable and transparent.

Another key learning was that standard communication scenarios and scope items save a tremendous amount of time and risk. Whenever we were able to rely on delivered content instead of custom interfaces, implementation effort, testing effort, and long-term maintenance were reduced noticeably.

Finally, extensibility played an important role in every single project. While most requirements could be solved using in-app Key User Extensibility, it was essential to define clear governance early on to avoid country-specific deviations and long-term technical debt.

This final part summarizes the key benefits and pitfalls we repeatedly encountered and shares our outlook on how SAP EHS in the Public Cloud will continue to evolve based on what we see today in real projects.

 

2. Benefits & Pitfalls

Integrating SAP EHS as part of a hybrid SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud landscape delivers strong business value but it also introduces architectural and organizational challenges that need to be managed carefully. In this chapter, we summarize the most important benefits and pitfalls we encountered across different customer projects.

2.1 Benefits

Fast Access to Innovation through Public Cloud Releases & AI

One of the strongest benefits we experienced in our projects was the direct access to new EHS functionality without classical upgrade projects. Unlike on-premise systems with long release cycles, customers benefit immediately from:

  • Regular Public Cloud releases and micro deliveries
  • Fast availability of new EHS features and regulatory content
  • Immediate access to SAP’s latest AI-driven innovations in EHS scenarios

This had a noticeable impact on time-to-value. Instead of waiting months for technical upgrades, functional improvements became available continuously. For several customers, this was also the first time AI-supported features in the EHS context could be evaluated productively.

Data Consistency and Compliance

A unified master data landscape turned out to be one of the biggest success factors across all projects. By integrating:

  • Employee data from SAP SuccessFactors
  • Business Partners & Materials from SAP MDG
  • Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

We ensured that EHS processes consistently relied on harmonized and validated master data. In practice, this was essential for:

  • Accurate incident reporting,
  • Reliable emissions calculations,
  • Correct assignment of responsibilities and workflows,
  • Audit-proof regulatory documentation.

Where master data was incomplete or inconsistent, downstream EHS processes were immediately affected.

Hybrid Architecture without Disruption

The side-by-side approach allowed customers to adopt EHS innovations in the Public Cloud without shutting down their existing on-premise environments. This enabled:

  • Gradual modernization instead of big-bang migrations,
  • Reduced transformation risk,
  • Protection of critical operational processes.

From a project perspective, this phased approach proved to be far more controllable than technical full-system replacements.

Standardized Interfaces and Scope Items

Whenever we could rely on standard SAP communication scenarios and scope items, the implantation became significantly faster and more stable. Examples include:

  • SAP_COM_0001, 0008, 0009, 0395
  • EHS scope items such as 3FP (Incident Management), 4XD (Emissions Management), and 54A (Health & Safety Management)

These accelerators reduced custom development effort, simplified testing, and aligned customer landscapes with SAP best practices.

Scalability and Future Readiness

The event-driven and API-first architecture of the Public Cloud supported scalable growth across all projects. Typical examples were:

  • Near real-time updated via SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh,
  • Flexible replication cycles for HR and MDG data,
  • Cloud-native extensibility for future EHS enhancements.

This ensured that the technical foundation remained adaptable as regulatory and sustainability requirements continued to evolve.

Extensibility for Business and Regulatory Needs

Across all customers, extensibility was required mainly for country-specific regulations, additional validations, or customer-specific reporting. In most cases, these requirements could be fulfilled using Key User (In-App) Extensibility, without breaking the clean core. This allowed customers to remain upgrade-stable while still meeting local compliance needs.

2.2 Pitfalls

Despite the strong benefits, several recurring challenges also appeared in almost every project.

System Landscape Complexity

Hybrid landscapes naturally involve multiple systems: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP MDG, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP BTP / Integration Suite. Without clear integration ownership, defined interface responsibilities, and coordinated technical design, landscapes quickly became difficult to operate and monitor.

Dependency on Master Data Quality

EHS processes are extremely sensitive to master data issues. We repeatedly saw how missing materials, outdated organizational requirements, or incorrect functional locations immediately blocked emissions calculations, risk assessments, and incident follow-ups. High master data quality is mandatory.

Custom Development Where Standard Content Is Missing

For some integration scenarios, especially Plant Maintenance integration for Functional Location and Equipment, custom iFlows were still required. This introduced additional development effort, higher testing effort, and long-term maintenance overhead.

Monitoring Challenges

End-to-end monitoring must cover:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud application logs
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise applications logs
  • SAP Master Data Governance application logs
  • SAP SuccessFactors message monitoring
  • SAP Integration Suite / iFlow monitoring

In several projects, missing monitoring initially led to delayed error detection and avoidable compliance risks.

Value Mapping and Harmonization

Incorrect or inconsistent value mappings between systems repeatedly caused replication failures. Early harmonization of organizational units, material types, equipment categories proved to be critical.

Validation of Services and Scope Items

Missing API activations or scope item assignments (e.g., API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION) frequently caused delays late in the project. Early validation of all required services became a key project success factor.

Governance and Limitations of Extensibility

Extensibility offers flexibility but without governance it quickly leads to:

  • Diverging country solutions,
  • Misaligned business logic
  • And long-term technical debt.

Additionally, Developer Extensibility is still limited to released APIs and BAdIs, which means that not every requirement can be solved purely with custom logic.

2.3 Summary of Benefits & Pitfalls

A successful EHS Public Cloud implementation balances the strengths of standardized integration content and clean-core extensibility with disciplined data governance and architectural planning. Organizations that manage this balance effectively can unlock the full potential of SAP EHS – enabling safe, compliant, and scalable EHS operations across the enterprise.

 

3. Outlook

Based on what we observe across current customer projects and SAP’s latest roadmap updates, SAP EHS in the Public Cloud is clearly evolving from a standalone compliance solution toward a central digital backbone for safety, risk, and environmental governance.

Many customers are already productive with core EHS scenarios today. At the same time, the functional scope continues to expand with each Public Cloud release. We see a strong move toward more standardized business content, broader regulatory coverage, and deeper support for environmental and sustainability-driven processes. As a result, future implementations will increasingly rely on configuration rather than custom development which significantly reduces implementation and upgrade effort.

Extensibility will nevertheless remain a key success factor. From our project experience, SAP is steadily increasing both the number and the quality of released APIs and cloud-compliant BAdIs. This allows customers to address local regulatory requirements and  compliant-specific validation logic in a clean-core compatible way. Especially Key User Extensibility is becoming more powerful, enabling business-driven adjustments without technical development.

In parallel, SAP BTP is gaining further importance for advanced EHS use cases. While this blog series focused on On-Stack Extensibility, we already see growing demand for advanced analytics and dashboards, cross-system workflow automation, and IoT-based hazard detection and emissions monitoring. These scenarios clearly go beyond standard transactional processing and position SAP BTP as a natural complement to SAP EHS in complex enterprise landscapes.

entry.title: Healthcare integration - Patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
In this blog, I'll give a sneak preview on various integration possibilities between Hospital Information Systems and an ERP system. I'll go into details about an integration package which creates patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. In the healthcare context, integration of patient data is important with most of the business process inside a hospital revolves around the patient. Before I go into details of the integration package, let’s first understand a few key words and use case.

Key words

SAP Cloud ERP Private refers to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

SAP BTP refers to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Integration Packages are a set of preconfigured integration artifacts for specific business process between various systems involved. 

Business Partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private is a central master data object that represents an organization, person, or group of people showing a business relationship.

FHIR refers to Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources. FHIR® is the registered trademarks of Health Level Seven International.

Perspective

There are many use cases where hospital data is available in an EMR (Electronic Medical Record) system like treatment, staffs and care-givers, billing and claims and so on. This data needs to be exchanged with SAP Cloud ERP Private to do business processes.

We need data exchange to improve agility and clarity for effective decision-making and to adapt for business transformation correctly.

Patient as a business partner is just one of the integration use cases. The integration package which I talk about in this blog offers template and guidance to integrate more such data. Entities like departments, vendors, personnel (Doctors and Hospital staffs), insurance, and so on, are some examples of data needed for integration. Such data integration will help in realizing business processes for finance, supply chain, workforce management and so on.

SAP Health Data Services for FHIR supports all the FHIR resources and serves as a domain model for data integration between EMR and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use Case

Why we need to represent the patient as a business partner? Let’s consider billing as an example at the hospital, where a patient could be a self-payer or a co-payer. We need to do Account Receivable management in SAP Cloud ERP Private for payment tracking and collection.  

Hence, the patient needs to be kept as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Onboarding - SAP Health Data Services for FHIR

For integration to be established, you need to have a key BTP service which is SAP Health Data Services for FHIR. For details, refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/f64d5f2b858042f791b64bdd4094df22/872ceb743a38498bb960b916de6cde5d.html

This onboarding steps are made simple using the BTP booster which automates all the onboarding steps for you, and you can refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/4613ca2972b540168ab4e03bf72023d7/de0e3033cda5477691db3bd521bbb163.html

Another step is to configure the patient resource in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR by profiling the patient resource. Refer the following link:

Setting up access control in cloud connector

Use the following link to complete the setup of access control in the cloud connector.

Importing Integration Package

Monitoring

When patient is created in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR, based on the preceding steps, the integration flow will automatically create the corresponding business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Conclusion

With this, I'll like to summarize the blog.

Blog offers you a step-by-step guide to realize integration for the patient data as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration(CI/CPI) Automated iFlow Comparison and Summarization Using Generative AI
entry.content:
When multiple teams collaborate on the same SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI) iFlow, changes can pile up quickly and it becomes difficult to pinpoint what was altered, who changed it, and which modifications must be transported to higher environments. To solve this, I built sapci_iflow_compare, a lightweight Streamlit app that fetches two iFlow XMLs and generates a technical, element-level diff, with an optional AI summary to make the results easy to review.

This blog walks through what the tool does and how to run it. It also explains why not to upload iFlow XMLs directly to public chatbots and how this approach keeps your content safer.

What the Solution Does

  • Connects to CI/CPI design‑time via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts to retrieve the selected iFlow’s ZIP and extract the .iflw XML for comparison (or accepts two local .iflw files) 
  • Matches nodes by id and performs a recursive comparison (attributes, text, structure), ignoring order differences where relevant, to produce a precise, developer‑friendly diff.
  • Displays the raw technical diff and (optionally) sends only the minimized difference report to Gemini for a human‑readable summary; you can disable the AI step entirely for strict confidentiality.

Architecture Overview

  • Inputs

Two CI/CPI design‑time endpoints (OAuth client credentials), or two local .iflw XMLs

 

  • API & Extraction

Calls /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts on your tenant to fetch the artifact content (ZIP) and extract the .iflw XML. 

 

  • Diff Engine

Parses both XMLs and generates an element‑level diff with attribute and text changes. 

 

  • Optional AI Summary

Sends only the diff to Gemini for summarization, not the entire iFlow XML, keeping exposure to a minimum

Connectivity & Security: Fetching iFlow XMLs via IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts

The tool connects to design‑time using the Integration Content OData API (OData V2), specifically the IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts resource exposed on SAP API Business Hub. This API supports downloading design‑time artifacts

Endpoint Pattern

  • Tenant base URL (design‑time):
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com
  • Resource path:
    /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Typical call:
    GET /api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts(Id='<ArtifactId>',Version='<ArtifactVersion>')/$value
    (Exact resource and operations are documented in the API reference.) [api.sap.com]

Authentication

Use OAuth2 Client Credentials against your XSUAA token endpoint to obtain an access token, then call the API with that token. SAP’s help portal details roles and inbound HTTP client setup for Integration Content OData API access

Option A: Configure credentials in config_file.json

If your policy permits, store per‑environment client credentials in the app’s JSON:

{
    "api1": {
      "name": "Source iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://source-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://source-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "source-client-id",
      "client_secret": "source-client-secret"
    },
    "api2": {
      "name": "Target iFlow Name",
      "url": "https://target-api-url",
      "oauth_token_url": "https://target-oauth-url",
      "client_id": "target-client-id",
      "client_secret": "target-client-secret"
    },
    "gemini_api_url": "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/gemini-2.0-flash:generateContent",
    "gemini_api_key": "your-gemini-api-key"
  }
This uses the design‑time OData endpoint documented by SAP and the standard client‑credentials grant for server‑to‑server integration.
 

Option B: Enter credentials at runtime in Streamlit

If storing secrets locally is a security concern, leave the client_id and client_secret blank in the config and enter them at runtime in the Streamlit UI. The app holds them in memory for the session and does not write them to disk. You’ll input:

  • Tenant API URL:
    https://<subaccount>-tmn.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/api/v1/IntegrationDesigntimeArtifacts
  • Token URL: https://<your-xsuaa-domain>/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: entered interactively in the UI

This approach adheres to the principle of minimizing persistence of credentials while leveraging the same SAP OData API

Setup & Run

  • Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare.git
cd sapci_iflow_compare
  • Install dependencies
pip3 install streamlit lxml requests
  • Choose your credential mode

Option A: Fill config_file.json with client credentials per environment.

Option B: Leave secrets empty and enter them at runtime via UI (recommended if local storage of secrets is not permitted).
(Both use the same SAP design‑time API.)

  • Run the app
python3 -m streamlit run iflow_compare.py
  • Click Compare iFlows to fetch, extract, and compare the two iFlow XMLs. Review the Raw Technical Diff and, if enabled, the AI Summary

Testing

  • I will use the Visual Studio code to run the .py file

  • Run the command

  • Page is opened in the browser as below and for simplicity, I will use Option A, using Config file, provide the config file path and click on compare iFlows

  • You can see the detailed differences of iFlow_1 and iFlow_2. If needed, it can be downloaded for detailed analysis

  • If needed, raw differences can be sent to Google Gemini and get the summary in readable format

This is just an idea and both difference logic and prompt can be extended as per the requirement

Recommended Use Cases

  1. Pre‑transport gate check
    Run a compare just before transport and attach the diff to your change ticket which mirrors best practice in community tools that emphasize confirming intended changes prior to moving artifacts. 

  2. Detect drift across packages/tenants
    Particularly useful when DEV and TEST coexist on the same tenant and packages fall out of sync is an issue documented by practitioners.

  3. Git workflows & automation
    Combine with GitHub sync (e.g., FlashPipe) and run the compare in a CI job or GitHub Action to block unintended changes on a pull request

Security: Why You Should Not Upload Full iFlow XMLs to Public Chatbots

Uploading raw iFlow XMLs (which may include endpoints, headers, and process logic) to public chatbots is risky:

  • Data training & retention: Public chatbot plans may use prompts to improve models and retain conversations (~30 days) even when training is disabled, which can violate internal policies for confidential data. (Enterprise plans have stronger guarantees, but that requires organizational adoption.) 

  • Real‑world incidents: Multiple organizations have restricted public chatbots after employees accidentally pasted confidential source code or internal materials; these cases underscore the leakage risk even when intentions are benign. 

  • SAP’s own caution: CI/CPI warns that placing sensitive values in headers or properties risks accidental exposure. Sending entire iFlow models externally increases that exposure surface. 

  • Safer pattern: Do your local comparison and, if you use AI, submit only a redacted difference report (no full iFlow XML) to your AI service or disable AI entirely. That is exactly how sapci_iflow_compare is designed

Conclusion

sapci_iflow_compare provides a repeatable, secure, and developer‑friendly way to compare iFlow changes across environments without exposing full iFlow XMLs to public chatbots. Whether you are preparing a transport, auditing changes, or reviewing a pull request, the element‑level diff and optional readable summary help you move faster with confidence. As conveyed previously, this is an idea which can be extended as per your requirements.

  • GitHub: Adarshrao23/sapci_iflow_compare

Please try it out, share feedback, and help improve the SAP integration ecosystem!

entry.title: Accelerate Your Lead-to-Cash Cycle: Seamless SAP CPQ Quoting from SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
In the competitive world of Lead-to-Cash, a streamlined workflow for managing quotes is no longer a luxury—it's the foundation for sales teams to hit their targets faster. When speed and accuracy matter, moving from Opportunity to Quote should be instantaneous. With the use of out of box integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, sales team can now initiate quote creation without ever leaving the familiar environment of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity screen (Guided Selling).

In this blog, I will explain some key aspects of the Quote integration from SAP Sales Cloud V2 to SAP CPQ, covering the key prerequisites and steps to set up the integration.

What This Integration Means to the end users:

Sales team can now leverage key features of sales quotation management directly from the SAP Sales Cloud V2 Guided Selling screen:

  • Direct Quote Creation from Opportunity object: Initiate an SAP CPQ quote directly from an existing opportunity in Sales Cloud V2. Customer and context data are transferred automatically, eliminating manual data entry and speeding up the sales cycle.
  • Seamless, Embedded CPQ Access: Launch the robust SAP CPQ quoting interface right from within Sales Cloud V2. With SSO enabled, you can access CPQ instantly without the need entering credentials.
  • Real-Time Data Consistency: Forget manual updates. Product quantities and final quote values are automatically synced back to the related Sales Cloud V2 opportunity in real-time, ensuring your pipeline data is always accurate and consistent.
  • Clean & Efficient API-Driven Architecture: Uses direct API communication between Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, with no shadow quote creation in Sales Cloud V2 — reducing redundancy and improving efficiency

Typical Use Case of CPQ Quotation from Sales Cloud V2

Initiating the Quote in Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity

The journey begins, naturally, in SAP Sales Cloud V2.

  • A user creates a new Opportunity, capturing essential details like customer information and sales context.
  • The user populates the Opportunity with initial Products and specifies the desired quantities. This sets the foundation for the quote.
  • To launch the formal quotation process, the user selects the External Sales Quote option.

This action instantly triggers the creation of a follow-up quote in SAP CPQ, powered by the standard content within SAP Cloud Integration.

Seamless Navigation and Pre-filled Data

Once the quote is generated in CPQ, the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity is immediately updated.

  • The newly created CPQ quote is visible directly within the Opportunity's Sales Quote section.
  • The user can seamlessly navigate to the full CPQ quoting interface by simply clicking the quotation hyperlink. This smooth transition is enabled by the External Link configuration in Sales Cloud V2.
  • Zero data entry is required for the initial quote. The CPQ quote screen is pre-filled with all the details pulled from the opportunity: products, quantities, and initial estimated prices.

Real-Time Synchronization and Data Consistency

As the quote matures in CPQ (pricing, configuration, discounting), the two systems remain perfectly synchronized:

  • Document Flow Update: The quote ID is instantly added to the Opportunity's Document Flow, providing a clear audit trail.
  • Real-Time Data Flush & Fill: As you update the quote in CPQ, a real-time synchronization pushes key data points—such as the quote status and discounts—back to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Instant Financial Updates: A quick refresh of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity instantly updates the Net Value and Negotiated Value, reflecting the latest changes made in CPQ.

Handling Complex Products: Configuring Quotes from Sales Cloud V2

While the standard workflow is great for simple product sets, what about complex, configurable products? The integration handles this seamlessly as well, keeping the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity as the starting point.

For products requiring detailed configuration (like machinery, specialized services, or complex bundles), the process adjusts slightly:

  • Skip the Opportunity Product Entry: You no longer need to add the product directly to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Launch CPQ for Configuration: Using the External Sales Quote option (as described previously), you initiate the quote in CPQ.
  • Configure and Save: Products are added and configured as required directly within the SAP CPQ interface.
  • Full Data Pushback: When you save the configured quote, the system ensures complete data transfer. The detailed configuration data—including the final products used, quantities, and calculated amounts—is then pushed back and added to the associated Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.

This capability ensures that whether the product is simple or highly complex, your Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity remains the accurate, single source of truth for the financial and product details of the deal.

Furthermore, if you want to embed the SAP CPQ screen directly in an Opportunity in Sales Cloud V2 using the Mashup Authoring extensibility feature.

 

Key Benefits of This Unified Approach

  • Seamlessly move from Opportunity to Quote and back, eliminating disruptive system-hopping for sales users.
  • Automated data transfer and real-time synchronization ensure consistent, accurate data between Sales Cloud V2 and CPQ, drastically reducing manual errors.
  • Leveraging prebuilt iFlows through SAP Cloud Integration minimizes custom development work, allowing you to deploy and realize benefits much faster.

 

Integration setup:

Before going through steps required to setup the integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, here are some prerequisites which you must meet:

  1. CPQ Requirement: Must use a CPQ tenant with the Quote 2.0 framework enabled.
  2. Integration Dependency: CPQ integration requires S/4HANA Integration to function (it is delivered for joint use).
  3. Master Data Setup: Complete the Initial Load of Master Data from S/4HANA to Sales Cloud V2, OR update all relevant Sales Cloud V2 External IDs with the S/4HANA System ID reference.
  4. ID Mapping Rule: ID mapping is indirect via S/4HANA. S/4HANA IDs are the primary reference between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2.
  5. Error Warning: Missing external IDs will trigger the error: "Outbound Synchronous request mapping failed."
  6. Configuration Constraint: The Opportunity to External Sales Quote configuration in Sales Cloud V2 must be unique (e.g., cannot configure for both CPQ and S/4HANA simultaneously). Multiple configurations result in the error: "Missing unique configuration for external quote communication."

Configurations required in SAP Sales Cloud:

  • Create Communication systems for S/4HANA & Cloud Integration (CPI connecting to CPQ) systems. Enable Inbound user & outbound communication for CPI system (configure the outbound https host as CPI runtime host).
  • Create a Communication Configuration by copying template “Integrate Opportunity with SAP CPQ”. Use the Cloud integration system name as comm. system.
  • In Properties comm configuration, set the S/4HANA system name
  • Add “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP S/4HANA, SAP ERP, or SAP CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to sync the quote data from CPQ to Sales V2. It will be trigger when you refresh the opportunity.
  • Add “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to update the follow up document details with CPQ quote.
  • Set the API path for Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity HTTP outbound with runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to trigger the CPQ quote creation from Sales Cloud V2 on click of External CPQ Quote submission.
  • In the inbound configuration, make sure the Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details is configured in the communication configuration. This inbound configuration will be used to update the Opportunity with CPQ status, amounts, discounts, etc data.
  • Configure External Link to navigate to SAP CPQ quote screen from Opportunity. For this, set the below:
    • External Object - Sales Quote
    • Communication system - CPI system name (created in step 1)
    • Link - https://<CPQDomain>.cpq.cloud.sap/fed/<federationName>/cart/edit?cartcompositenumber=${displayId}

Configurations required in SAP Cloud Integration:

  • Use the Cloud Integration standard package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ  to integrate sales quotes between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ.
  • Below are key interfaces to be configured:

Create Follow-up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity (to create the quote in CPQ)

Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ (to update the follow-up document with quote id from CPQ)

Retrieve Document Flow from CPQ (to update the opportunity with Quote ID, set primary quote)

Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details (to update opportunity with CPQ quote data like negotiation amount, discounts, etc when the quote is saved or submitted)

Additionally, if you are using subscription products in opportunity Sales Cloud V2, then use Update Subscription Product Fields in SAP CPQ Quote to sync the quote updates from CPQ to Sales Cloud.

  • Configure the Value Mapping with respective processing statuses, rejection statuses, owner names between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2 systems.

Configurations required in SAP CPQ:

  • Subscribe to Quote events to update the Sales Cloud opportunity with Quote data. You can use QuoteEvent (OnSaveAction) to trigger Cloud integration iflow Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details.
  • If directly login is required with SSO, enable SSO with federation settings between both Sales cloud v2 and CPQ to be setup using SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service in BTP.

References links:

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP CPQ Quote 2.0

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP Sales Cloud V2

Quote integration between SAP CPQ and Sales Cloud V2

Enable SSO in SAP CPQ

Enable SSO in Sales Cloud V2
